name: The Conjuring: The Devil Made Me Do It
desc: ​​There’s hardly a dull moment in ‘The Conjuring: The Devil Made Me Do It.’ This one takes the franchise to newer highs revealing a chilling story of terror, murders and the unknown evil.

name: Minari
desc: Lee Isaac Chung’s simple little film about a family finding its place in the world is rooted in reality and Korean culture. It smells of earth and rain and our sense of belonging to the land that feeds our stomachs.

name: The Father
desc: Zellman’s ‘The Father’ is a lot more than a film that merely exists to tell you a story. This is an experience and a journey into an unstable world that is just as real, as it is make-believe.

name: The Mauritanian
desc: ‘The Mauritanian’ is a lot of things and in-depth representation of the primary subject and the simmering issues underneath is not one of them. And yet, with conviction, we say it relievers what it promises to do: give peace and forgiveness a chance. Both to Slahi and America.

name: Godzilla Vs. Kong
desc: Delivers on its promise as a massive monster clash and adrenaline-driven movie lovers will be visually rewarded for catching this spectacle in cinemas.

name: The Courier
desc: Even though espionage buffs may find some of the genre tropes familiar, ‘The Courier’ is an enjoyable old-fashioned thriller that does not need to exaggerate to impress.

name: Raya And The Last Dragon
desc: It is a complete package with something for everyone. It’s a spirited fantasy adventure for the children, an inspiring young warrior princess, who defines women empowerment and a universally binding emotional fabric.

name: Judas And The Black Messiah
desc: ‘Pitched as a biographical, ‘Judas and the Black Messiah’ is almost like a hagiography of its protagonist Fred Hampton (played superbly by Daniel Kaluuya). But the way co-writer and director Shaka King maneuvers through one of American history’s darkest chapters, is not only convincing and fascinating but also hugely riveting in its approach.

name: Tom & Jerry
desc: Isn’t deep or complicated, but works as a fun, nostalgic trip that will enthral kids while bringing back childhood memories for adults who grew up on the beloved series.

name: Breaking News In Yuba County
desc: Breaking News In Yuba County is a English movie released on 19 Feb, 2021. The movie is directed by Tate Taylor and  featured Mila Kunis, Allison Janney, Juliette Lewis and Ellen Barkin as lead characters. Other popular actors who were roped in for Breaking News In Yuba County are Chris Lowell, Awkwafina, Jimmi Simpson and Matthew Modine

name: Our Friend
desc: Our Friend is a English movie released on 12 Feb, 2021. The movie is directed by Gabriela Cowperthwaite and  featured Jason Segel, Isabella Kai, Violet McGraw and Casey Affleck as lead characters.Other popular actors who were roped in for Our Friend is and Dakota Johnson

name: Monster Hunter
desc: All of 130 minutes, ‘Monster Hunter,’ packs in too many punches in an attempt to become an all-out action extravaganza. But for a film that tells the story of the real people, fighting the beasts of the new world, it feels a lot less thrilling than its source material. Are you game?

name: The Little Things
desc: Hancock’s crime thriller is a dated attempt that tells an interesting story with some mature performances and a lesson on how the little things can have a big impact.

name: Misbehaviour
desc: ‘Misbehaviour’ is a bit too safe and crowd-pleasing but reminds us that some things are still worth standing up for.

name: The Secret Garden
desc: All the characters and all of it is in service of a very workable script that tries too hard to make us believe in the magic of the garden – something that should come naturally, anyway. In doing so, the writing only partially succeeds in translating the magic of the book into the film.

name: The Croods: A New Age
desc: The Croods: A New Age is a English movie released on 23 Dec, 2020. The movie is directed by Joel Crawford and  featured Nicolas Cage,  Emma Stone,  Ryan Reynolds and  Catherine Keener as lead characters. Other popular actors who were roped in for The Croods: A New Age are  Clark Duke and  Cloris Leachman

name: Hard Kill
desc: Shot entirely in an abandoned factory, ‘Hard Kill’ lacks imagination and elements to entertain. Despite some known faces, it comes across as lazy B-grade rip off of a thrilling action extravaganza that could have been a lot more deserving of its title.

name: Wonder Woman 1984
desc: Overall, ‘WW84’ is a clean and wholesome mass entertainer that dutifully ticks all the boxes. From action and adventure to drama and emotions, it’s all here to pull the audience back to the big screen.

name: The Secrets We Keep
desc: Film buffs will be able to identify the foreshadowing that makes the climax slightly predictable but the performances and premise make 'The Secrets We Keep' a reasonably entertaining watch.

name: Come Away
desc: Angelina Jolie is at her usual best playing a grieving mother with restraint and poise, but it is David Oyelowo’s fatherly emotions that will touch your heart. He is brilliant as the man torn between his shady past and glum present, but perhaps a bright future, thanks to his adorable children.

name: The Personal History Of David Copperfield
desc: Despite all its excellent performances, the film doesn’t quite deliver as a lightheaded yet heartwarming take on a classic tale.

name: Antebellum
desc: ‘Antebellum’ follows a rather simple notion made popular by Nobel Prize winning American writer Willaim Faulkner that read, ‘Past is never dead. It’s not even past.’

name: Come Play
desc: It's not an entirely unique concept but 'Come Play' is the kind of horror flick that can resonate with kids without giving them the chills that they won't recover from. It does so without resorting to excessive violence, blood and gore or nudity.

name: Target Number One
desc: This crime drama sets out to honour the exposé that Malarek had written back in 1989, which, in turn, leads to cracking the cover-up wide open. Unfortunately, none of these sentiments shine through in its visual representation. All we get is a stubborn journalist and his relentless pursuit to seek the truth. The journey in between has been dropped, and that in itself is a criminal offence.

name: Trolls World Tour
desc: Once again, ‘Trolls Word Tour’ reiterates what we have known all along but some of us chose to ignore or may have forgotten: music is the universal language of the universe.

name: Relic
desc: ‘Relic’ moves at an unhurried pace but never does it drag. Along with its surreal and ghostly atmospherics, it explores the most basic human emotions.

name: The Witches
desc: ‘The Witches’ is a simple story made grandly entertaining with all its crafty ingredients firmly in place. Enough to cast its magic spell on children of all ages.

name: The New Mutants
desc: With all its power play, ‘The New Mutants’ seems more like a complex campus drama with teenage squabbles and first kisses rather than a sophisticated making of the next breed of X-Men.​​

name: Never Steal A Man's Second Chance: Honest Thief
desc: ‘Honest Thief’ is an all too familiar Liam Neeson outing. But a unique plot with unpretentious performances and some thrilling moments make it worth your while. Honest!

name: The Outpost
desc: ‘The Outpost’ is crafted with precision, expertise and experience. It’s a war drama that transports you to the battlefield in all its cinematic brilliance.

name: The War With Grandpa
desc: ‘The War with Grandpa’ is no more than a bunch of gags put together in staged set pieces, but thankfully, it never pretends to be more than that either. Watch it for the collective innocence and the harmless buffoonery by people of all ages.

name: The Silencing
desc: ‘The Silencing’ is one of those serial killer sagas that’s not so much about what it is telling you, but how it is telling you. And that’s where it makes quite a killing.

name: Greenland
desc: Greenland is a slow-burning, mature and nuanced take on a life-altering and destructive fictional event that is all too familiar in today’s time. It’s as grounded as it is gritty, leaving you emotionally heavy and cinematically satisfied.

name: Scoob!
desc: ‘Scoob!’ is clearly more of a rehash than reinvention with some contemporary coolness and imagination so it can appeal to today’s smartphone generation. The result is mildly entertaining, but nothing exceptional.

name: Unhinged
desc: ‘Unhinged’ isn’t the best road rage movie to have hit the marquee, but it does drive home its point ‘bloody’ well. And it does so with less gun play and more horsepower.

name: Bill & Ted Face The Music
desc: Keeping up with the legacy of Bill and Ted’s trademark goofiness, this third instalment builds it up further and takes its bizarre and adventurous plot to a whole new level of madness. But it remains silly as ever.

name: Ava
desc: It’s Jessica Chastain’s charisma and star power that saves the day for Ava. Otherwise, it’s an unimaginative plot with less thrill and many clichés.

name: The Secret: Dare To Dream
desc: While ‘The Secret’ doesn’t tell you what you don’t know already, it does so with simplicity and sensitivity. Overall, it’s a well-meaning film that gives you cosmic hope in a way that leaves you entertained and smiling.

name: Tenet
desc: The film’s screenplay keeps underlining and explaining its layered plot about technology that can reverse time. Thankfully, it does so with stunning cinematography (Hoyte Van Hoytema) and action-packed scenes that are executed with a natural flair and finesse.

name: Parasite
desc: With an insightful and searing exploration of human behavior, ‘Parasite’ is a masterfully crafted film that is a definite must watch.

name: Bloodshot
desc: ‘Bloodshot’ is a decent attempt that scores on its ambitious sci-fi imagination and a superhero, who is always ready for the action.

name: Onward
desc: The animation is top-notch and visually appealing. The characters are adequately cartoonish and also highly relatable and humane.

name: The Invisible Man
desc: One of the rare psychological horror-thrillers that should come with a trigger warning, ‘The Invisible Man’ subverts many genre tropes to keep you looking over your shoulder well after the credits roll.

name: Sonic The Hedgehog
desc: Sonic The Hedghog is a little ball of super energy packed with action, adventure and entertainment in an adorable package – perfect to fight your boredom blues.

name: Brahms: The Boy II
desc: Besides some jump scares and the sporadic unsettling visuals, you won’t get much bang for your buck as a horror fan, due to this film's frustrating narrative.

name: Fantasy Island
desc: The concept of a modern-day genie in a posh resort sounds more than appealing in theory, but in reality, that initial curiosity fizzles out soon after and is swiftly replaced by perplexity.

name: Little Women
desc: Marked by strong performances and endearing characters, ‘Little Women’ is a relevant retelling of a classic bestseller that is as poetic as it is real.

name: The Rhythm Section
desc: The Rhythm Section is a English movie released on 31 Jan, 2020. The movie is directed by Reed Morano and  featured Blake Lively,  Jude Law,  Daniel Mays and Max Casella as lead characters. Other popular actors who were roped in for The Rhythm Section are Geoff Bell, Raza Jaffrey and Richard Brake

name: Bad Boys For Life
desc: This one carries forward the legacy of the bad boys franchise and the magic of its leading men ensure that third time’s a charm.

name: Jojo Rabbit
desc: With its satirical stance, Jojo Rabbit is a bold film that hits hard and makes for an overwhelming cinematic experience.

name: Shaun The Sheep Movie: Farmageddon
desc: The visuals and effects that one gets to see on screen are top-notch and the fact that it is a tightly edited script (only 86 minutes long) makes this film an ocular delight to witness.

name: Judy
desc: Although insightful moments are missing from most of the film, ‘Judy’ stands strong on Zellweger’s career-defining performance.

name: A Beautiful Day In The Neighborhood
Dolittle
desc: Technicalities and screenplay aside, the tonality is fun and bubbly, and as far as a family film goes, ‘Dolittle’ is sure to be a hit with kids, who seem to be the film's target audience.

name: Like a Boss
desc: The experience of watching ‘Like A Boss’ is like revisiting high school in a not-so-nostalgic way. But, if you are grateful for your bosom buddy and would like to share a light moment with him/her, watch it for the feels.

name: Richard Jewell
desc: A security guard becomes a hero after finding an explosive device, but soon comes under scrutiny by the FBI as a prime suspect.

name: The Informer
desc: ‘The Informer’ is an entertaining thriller with gritty action scenes that makes full use of its plot to drive the suspense.

name: The Grudge
desc: Despite a haunting tonality that’s faithfully maintained throughout, ‘The Grudge’ is likely to leave most viewers unsatisfied.

name: Bombshell
desc: Although the sum isn’t greater than its parts, this is an essential film that needs to be watched, considering the significance of its real-life events

name: Spies In Disguise
desc: ‘Spies in Disguise’ may not be revolutionary in any way, but it is a fun and entertaining family film appropriate for the holidays.

name: Star Wars: The Rise Of Skywalker
desc: Does enough to wrap up the new trilogy but it becomes evident that its overarching narrative wasn’t clearly outlined, and it shows.

name: The Warrior Queen Of Jhansi
desc: Devika Bhise in the role of Rani Laxmibai often seems out of her depth. While she handles the dramatic scenes well, it’s the action scenes that leave her looking ordinary.

name: The Good Liar
desc: ‘The Good Liar’ works better as an acting masterclass by its brilliant lead performers, rather than a taut and rewarding storytelling experience.

name: Hotel Mumbai
desc: Based on true events, Hotel Mumbai recounts the 26/11 carnage that shook Mumbai in 2008, focusing on the terrorist attack inside the iconic Taj Mahal Hotel.

name: Remember Amnesia
desc: In theory, this dramedy seems to have ticked the right boxes, but what in reality, it is a product that hardly ever manages to make you laugh or evoke a sense of sympathy.

name: 21 Bridges
desc: Not a groundbreaking film by any means, but '21 Bridges' is still quite entertaining due to compelling action and performances.

name: Frozen 2
genre: Animation Adventure Comedy Family Fantasy Musical
desc: ​It’s a tall order to expect this sequel to capture the lightning-in-a-bottle magic of the original, but Frozen 2’s stunning eye-candy and humour will be enjoyable enough for its younger core audience.

name: Motherless Brooklyn
desc: ‘Motherless Brooklyn’ has got the mood and atmosphere right, but struggles with the pace of the story and narration intricacies.

name: Charlie's Angels
desc: The female-centric messaging of this new ‘Charlie’s Angels’ is well-intended, but the execution doesn’t always do it justice.

name: Ford v. Ferrari
desc: Motorheads and racing fans are guaranteed to love ‘Ford v Ferrari’, but even the casual moviegoer will get a kick out of it.

name: Doctor Sleep
desc: This reflective horror flick isn’t for everyone, but if you enjoyed 'The Shining', you'd undoubtedly find this to be a worthy successor.

name: Midway
desc: Midway manages to educate, inform and entertain its audience about a historic battle that changed the course of World War II in the Pacific.

name: Last Christmas
desc: Cheesy reveal aside, ‘Last Christmas’ is quite enjoyable with good performances, a pleasant background score and witty humour with enough ‘feelgood’ factor.

name: The Addams Family
desc: Despite the predictabilty of the plot and average special effects, 'The Addams Family' works to a reasonable extent mainly because of its characters and the layered themes.

name: The Current War
desc: Historical inaccuracies notwithstanding, ‘The Current War’ is sufficiently engaging and shines bright enough, powered by its competent cast.

name: Terminator: Dark Fate
desc: A satisfying addition to James Cameron’s Terminator films that does just enough to bring the franchise back from the dead.

name: Maleficent: Mistress Of Evil
desc: With widespread death and destruction, this fairytale costume drama is by no means a child’s play. However, it has enough live-action magic to bring the big screen alive.

name: Downton Abbey
desc: Combined with impeccable costume design, attention to production details, and dreamy cinematography, ‘Downton Abbey’ is a treat for fans of the series who will thoroughly enjoy this big-screen version.

name: Gemini Man
desc: Despite its technological achievements combined with the best efforts of an otherwise charismatic Will Smith along with a capable cast, and a visionary director, ‘Gemini Man’ isn’t able to take off due to a dull script.

name: Joker
desc: It's simultaneously difficult to watch and yet, impossible to take your eyes off Joaquin Phoenix in this film that may become the definitive origin tale of the Joker.

name: Hustlers
desc: Despite the best efforts of JLo, there’s a lot of glamour but not enough depth required to make 'Hustlers' a memorable film, however, it may be just enough for a night out.

name: Official Secrets
desc: For a film that focuses on a relatively lesser known episode of a massive political development in our recent history, Official Secrets manages to squeeze in all the crucial aspects around it.

name: Abominable
desc: Despite an unoriginal premise, the film’s focus on its visual dazzle and its sensitivity towards nature and family values are bound to win hearts all around.

name: Rambo: Last Blood
desc: Rambo: Last Blood isn’t as hard-hitting as intended, but hardcore fans of the old-school style of generic action storytelling may find some nostalgic amusement.

name: The Goldfinch
desc: It is melancholic and, thanks to its source material, often shows the potential of reaching out to the dark corners of one's heart and soul.

name: Ready Or Not
desc: 'Ready Or Not' stays fresh and entertaining as it embraces its absurdity while staying focused on the core theme – family.

name: IT: Chapter Two
desc: Despite a complex narrative and an exhausting runtime, there's a lot going on in this sequel that manages to engage you.

name: 47 Meters Down: Uncaged
desc: Instead of embracing the entertaining cheesiness of such a far-fetched premise, co-writer and director Johannes Roberts tries to stick to the basics of a creature feature and fails to create anything memorable.

name: The Kitchen
desc: The setting is New York’s Hell’s Kitchen in 1978 but you can’t be blamed at times if you think if you’re watching a parody film on that era, with all the possible clichés thrown in.

name: The Angry Birds Movie 2
desc: Right from the first scene, it’s established that this sequel of ‘The Angry Birds’ is strictly a kiddie flick and thankfully, it never tries to be anything other than that.

name: Crawl
desc: Inspired by classic creature features, director Alexandre Aja doesn’t aim to do anything new for the genre but uses a strong setup and solid performances to deliver a tense and satisfying film for thrill-seekers.

name: Once Upon A Time In Hollywood
desc: ‘Once Upon a Time in Hollywood’ proves, yet again, that there’s no other cinematic storyteller quite like Quentin Tarantino.

name: Scary Stories To Tell In The Dark
desc: 'Scary Stories To Tell In The Dark' ends up as a jumble of unexplored ideas onscreen rather than a cohesive narrative. However, if you only enjoy horror films for creepy monsters, you’ll manage to get a kick or two.

name: Dora And The Lost City Of Gold
desc: Despite its obvious flaws, ‘Dora and the Lost City of Gold’ is self-aware, and its whimsical tonality is held together by a strong lead to make for a family-friendly watch.

name: Fast & Furious: Hobbs & Shaw
desc: This spin-off has just enough self-aware humour, a touch of emotion, a few surprise cameos, and gallons of set-piece fuel to stand on its own beefy legs.

name: The Lion King
desc: This family-favourite comes to life and should trigger enough awe-inspiring moments thanks to its visual achievements, despite being an uninspired shot-by-shot, track-by-track remake that doesn't always make full use of its talented cast.

name: Yesterday
desc: There's not enough of the whimsical edge that made the film promising, nor are there any attempts at reason, and while it may or may not please fans of The Beatles, ‘Yesterday’ is a breezy, fun watch with ample charm.

name: Shoplifters
desc: The performances by Kirin Kiri, Lily, Sakura Ando and Mayu Matsuoka are heartfelt and brilliant. But it’s the two children - Jyo Kairi, Miyu Sasaki - who are outstanding and leave the maximum impact.

name: Spider-Man: Far From Home
desc: 'Spider-Man: Far From Home' is a lot of fun but more importantly, the film is also a satisfying continuation and way forward for the MCU, as Tom Holland proves he’s more than capable of carrying an Avengers’ film on his young shoulders.

name: Annabelle Comes Home
desc: 'Annabelle Comes Home' is a textbook scarefest that delivers on its promise to haunt, without being complicated or preachy about Gods and demons.

name: Anna
desc: There’s some fun to be had in this bonkers spy-thriller led by a tough female protagonist, but the gasps eventually develop into groans as 'Anna' tries to shock you at every turn.

name: The Extraordinary Journey Of The Fakir
Toy Story 4
desc: What really makes Toy Story 4 special is its strong emotional fabric woven into a riveting narrative. Dialogues are laced with high emotional impact and are delivered effectively in familiar voices.

name: Men In Black International
desc: Chris Hemsworth and Tessa Thompson fans may be able to sit this through, but Men In Black International proves that no amount of charisma can substitute a strong screenplay.

name: The Secret Life Of Pets 2
desc: Max faces new fears and relationship dynamics as his owner Katie now has a baby. And there are also a few rescue missions added into the mix!

name: X-Men: Dark Phoenix
desc: Despite good performances, 'Dark Phoenix' is a letdown for a number of reasons, least of all because the female characters in this film take prominence, and they deserve better.

name: Rocketman
desc: ‘Rocketman’ raises the bar of what can be achieved in a musical biography with brilliant performances, particularly by Taron Egerton, and an unflinching look into Elton John's rockstar life.

name: Godzilla: King Of The Monsters
desc: Despite the plot’s blatant stupidity, the visuals showcasing destruction of epic proportion and the terrifying arrival of King Godzilla offer some solid jump scares.

name: Long Shot
desc: Beyond satire that’s anything but politically correct, ‘Long Shot’ is a definite crowd-pleaser with its heart in the right place and undeniable chemistry between its unlikely lead pair.

name: Brightburn
desc: ‘Brightburn’ proves there’s more to the superhero genre if seen from a different perspective but its execution lacks conviction, despite ample jump scares and gore to justify being a horror flick.

name: Aladdin
desc: The film is congenial and establishes the ‘feel-good’ factor from frame one and maintains it till the curtains are drawn.

name: The Hustle
desc: The storyline pretty much sticks to that of 'Dirty Rotten Scoundrels' so there is nothing new there. At just one and half hours this one feels like a drag after a point.

name: John Wick: Chapter 3 - Parabellum
desc: ‘Parabellum’ more than makes up for what it lacks in depth, with stunning visuals and captivating action, as Keanu Reeves and the rest of the cast make yet another essential entry in this series.

name: The Intruder
desc: Writer David Loughery keeps the proceedings paced out with regular shout-at-the-screen scares, but it’s the predictability of the plot that often kills the fun.

name: Pokémon Detective Pikachu
desc: Ryan Reynolds infuses the tiny, yellow, rodent-like creature with a distinct personality that instantly draws you into the film despite its clumsy plot and screenplay

name: A Dog’s Way Home
desc: Despite the predictable premise, the film embraces what it is – a wholesome family movie catering to animal lovers.

name: After
desc: There are not many twists and the narrative is simple. However, it hoodwinks you into feeling that something really unusual will happen - whether or not it does, is for you to find out.

name: Avengers: Endgame
desc: It is a befitting tribute to the Cinematic Universe that has spawned larger than life superheroes and super fans. And if you’re not a fan yet, chances are, you might become one after watching this instalment.

name: The Curse Of The Weeping Woman
desc: Predictable jump scare treatment and dragging exposition take out all the potential from this horror film despite decent performances.

name: Hellboy
desc: Despite McShane and Harbour’s best efforts, this exhaustive ‘end-of-the-world’ story is unable to raise as much hell as it should.

name: Pet Sematary
desc: Although the harrowing setup is squandered as not enough time is spent on character development, the very nature of this story is unsettling enough to compel you to see it through, helped by its taut run-time, and one terrifying cat!

name: Fighting With My Family
desc: Film’s pace gets a bit sluggish in parts, but the oddball family dynamics come to the rescue. There is a constant flow of organic humour, seamlessly written into the characters.

name: Shazam
desc: Shazam is a English movie released on 5 Apr, 2019. The movie is directed by David F Sandberg and  featured Zachary Levi, Mark Strong, Michelle Borth and Adam Brody as lead characters.Other popular actors who were roped in for Shazam is and Ross Butler

name: Five Feet Apart
desc: Despite being stretched out, Five Feet Apart relies on its cast to deliver some unexpected heartfelt moments that often surpass the cliches of a young adult tragic romance.

name: Dumbo
desc: While there are problems such as predictability, caricature characters and a sluggish pace, 'Dumbo' has its moments. Overall, it’s a harmless family entertainer for children of all ages.​​

name: The Least Of These: The Graham Staines Story
desc: A deeply provocative and disturbing issue of ‘religious conversion’ and a brutal and barbaric hate crime that followed, forms the story of this social drama.

name: How To Train Your Dragon: The Hidden World
desc: 'How To Train Your Dragon: The Hidden World' is a visually stunning and emotionally satisfying conclusion to a surprisingly well-rounded 'vikings & dragons' trilogy that will appeal to various age groups for different reasons.

name: Captain Marvel
desc: 'Captain Marvel' encounters some speed bumps, courtesy of the usual superhero origin issues that have troubled the genre, but it succeeds in establishing Carol Danvers as a bonafide bad-ass, and why the Avengers are a much stronger team with her on their side.

name: The Wife
desc: ‘The Wife’ is a timely examination of the adage – behind every great man, there’s a great woman - with a masterclass in acting by Glenn Close

name: The Lego Movie 2: The Second Part
desc: The makers continue to retain this world’s unique sense of self-aware humour and graphic style in this sequel, proving that the franchise is here to stay.

name: Alita: Battle Angel
desc: ‘Alita: Battle Angel’ is another testament to the power of big-screen extravaganzas even though there are no great surprises in its ‘last-of-her-kind’ narrative.

name: Escape Room
desc: Barring a couple of surprises in 'Escape Room', whatever investment is made into the proceedings stunningly fails towards the last lap and dramatically crashes in the climax

name: Mary Queen Of Scots
desc: ‘Mary Queen of the Scots’ has a timely premise with a lot to say about toxic masculinity and women empowerment but never gets around to it, despite its brief sparks of brilliance that quickly die out before catching fire.

name: One Less God
desc: ‘One Less God’ revisits Mumbai's 26/11 through this fictional story that falters in some areas but works well enough as a whole.

name: Glass
desc: Glass is terrific but has its underwhelming moments. However, if you are the type who likes the journey regardless of the destination, Glass is your film.

name: Second Act
desc: Instead of capitalising on its likeable cast and the still sensational Jennifer Lopez to make a fun, breezy and light-hearted rom-com, the film resorts to insulting your intelligence, especially in its ‘second act’.

name: Bumblebee
desc: 'Bumblebee' is certainly the best example of what this franchise is meant to be, and should it continue on this path, the Transformers can become exciting and enjoyable all over again.

name: Aquaman
desc: Jason Momoa, combined with some insane action setpieces, make for convincing reasons to dive into the world of ‘Aquaman’.

name: Ben Is Back
desc: Despite its tonal shifts, ‘Ben is Back’ makes the most of its cast to put together a heartfelt film on the strength of parental love against all odds.

name: Spider-Man: Into The Spider-Verse
desc: ‘Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse’ is a bold attempt to tell one of the most ‘out there’ stories in the comic book world in which all film-making components come together to create arguably one of the best Spider-Man films.

name: The Possession Of Hannah Grace
desc: 'Possession of Hannah Grace' squanders an interesting protagonist only to throw a lot of tropes at the screen that leaves you unimpressed in a forgettable film.

name: The Girl In The Spider's Web
desc: The Girl in the Spider's Web makes for an engaging watch as a stand-alone crime thriller. It even tones down the brutal violence a bit.

name: Ralph Breaks The Internet: Wreck It Ralph 2
genre: Comedy Animation Adventure Family Fantasy Drama
desc: It might not have the surprise elements of the original, but ‘Ralph Breaks the Internet’ is a thoroughly enjoyable visual treat for children of all ages.

name: A Private War
desc: ‘A Private War’ is filled with brutal, powerful images that will stick with you well after the movie is done, and succeeds in paying homage to Marie Colvin who put her life on the line while documenting others.

name: Creed II
desc: Strong performances combined with the sturdy, albeit measured direction by Steven Caple Jr., ensure that although ‘Creed II’ comes across as formulaic, there’s no shame in enjoying it for nostalgic reasons.

name: Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes Of Grindelwald
desc: While there are ample references to Hogwarts and cameos to satisfy fans, ‘The Crimes of Grindelwald’ has a lot of dense exposition that’s bound to baffle others, making this 'Fantastic Beasts' entry feel more like a setup than a standalone entity.

name: Bohemian Rhapsody
desc: There was more to Freddie Mercury than his nonconformist, outrageous and wild shindigs. Bohemian Rhapsody celebrates his undying spirit beautifully through his music. Though the story keeps you hooked, Rami Malek’s Oscar worthy performance outshines it all.

name: The Grinch
desc: 'The Grinch' isn't exactly groundbreaking or fresh, but it has just enough Christmas magic to justify another modern retelling of an old story.

name: The Nutcracker And The Four Realms
desc: The Nutcracker And The Four Realms is a English movie released on 2 Nov, 2018. The movie is directed by Lasse Hallstrom and  featured Keira Knightley,  Morgan Freeman,  Helen Mirren and  Mackenzie Foy as lead characters. Other popular actors who were roped in for The Nutcracker And The Four Realms are  Matthew Macfadyen,  Eugenio Derbez, Miranda Hart and Ellie Bamber

name: Hunter Killer
desc: The film comes across as another excuse for 'good ole' American patriotism to save the world, and feels more than slightly outdated in the current environment.

name: Halloween
desc: Jamie Lee Curtis brings depth the role of Laurie Strode in this slasher flick that works best when it sticks to the basics, and revives the almost forgotten horror sub-genre.

name: First Man
desc: Brilliantly crafted and hypnotic from beginning to end, First Man is immersive, intimate and meditative — a stunning piece of work that leaves you thinking about it, way after it's over.

name: A Star Is Born
desc: Bradley Cooper has something new to say in this version, and Lady Gaga belts it out loud and clear to make this a definite contender in numerous categories during awards season.

name: Venom
desc: Tom Hardy proves that he’s more than equipped to play the sentient symbiote, but this film is concerned mainly with stomping from one plot point to the next, at the cost of character development.

name: Village Rockstars
desc: Village Rockstars is heartbreaking and uplifting in equal measure. A young girl and her mother’s woes and misery is not music to the ears but their spirit, is.

name: Smallfoot
desc: The animation is delightful without being over the top. The script is pretty straightforward and will keep kids entertained although it may not find many adult takers.

name: Peppermint
desc: 'Peppermint' is one of those movies that is riddled with ridiculous clichés and the crucial twists and turns in the diegesis comes from a dangerous territory: lazy writing.

name: Early Man
desc: The uncanny (script) resemblance to one of our very few Oscar honours, which had cricket as its game of conflict between the weak and the powerful, is too hard to brush off.

name: The House With A Clock In Its Walls
desc: The spirited combination of Black and Blanchett along with gorgeous production and costume design, make this an entertaining family adventure.

name: Destination Wedding
desc: The sole reason to watch these two actors is their undeniable charm that shines through their dysfunctional characters who spew volumes of dialogue that sound too fabricated to be real.

name: The Predator
desc: 'The Predator' revisits the testosterone-fuelled grandiosity of the 80's with quirky humour and gripping action that comes at the cost of a strong, self-contained story.

name: The Nun
desc: 'The Nun' does a small favour for the 'Conjuring' franchise with a derivative plot that relies solely on the eerie soundtrack and discomforting vibe to deliver predictable jump scares.

name: Searching
desc: Indian-origin filmmaker Aneesh Chaganty’s feature film debut is a gem of a high-concept thriller with human emotions at the heart of it. The film reflects on the biggest irony of our lives — loneliness and human disconnect in times of online connectivity.

name: Papillon
desc: Although the performances are engaging enough, this remake sorely lacks a robust screenplay to give us the essential insight into a man who refused to break.

name: Alpha
desc: Discerning viewers will be mesmerized by its spectacular cinematography and technical wizardry but the gritty and heart-warming tale of ‘Alpha’ makes it essential viewing for every dog-lover.

name: The Spy Who Dumped Me
desc: There’s a lot of fun to be had with some unexpected surprises and just enough laughs to keep you reasonably entertained by its affable lead pair

name: Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again
desc: ‘Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again’ is a breezy, feel-good musical made for ABBA fans that sweeps you away with a wave of nostalgia to make you forget the point of the movie in the first place.

name: Mission: Impossible - Fallout
desc: ‘Mission: Impossible – Fallout’ has a great mix of plot, pacing and performances that undeniably makes it the best entry in the franchise.

name: Skyscraper
desc: This generic film, with the always charismatic Dwayne Johnson, might be worth your money and time only if your expectations aren't sky-high and you enjoy predicting what happens next in movies,

name: Hotel Artemis
desc: Dark, brooding and eerie - Hotel Artemis is a suspenseful and atmospheric crime thriller that works on your mind but fails to build upon the tension created.

name: Tag
desc: ‘Tag’ is based on a true-life story that’s really adorable, but the film fails to impress with its screenplay and execution.

name: Isle Of Dogs
desc: A charming story with fascinating characters voiced by a near-perfect cast is brought to life by Wes Anderson’s iconic cinematography and meticulous animation.

name: Hereditary
desc: If you are looking to truly and completely get scared, 'Hereditary' will ensure that happens in the best and most unexpected way possible.

name: The Incredibles 2
desc: ‘Incredibles 2’ proves to be worth the wait with ample comedy and eye-popping action for all ages, while having an engaging story.

name: Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom
desc: ‘Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom’ excels when it allows the real stars – the CGI dinosaurs – to shine, and roar louder than most of their predecessors.

name: You Were Never Really Here
desc: You Were Never Really Here is taut, gritty, weird and unsettling. This one’s a must watch, especially for the raw brilliance of Joaquin Phoenix.

name: Monster Hunt 2
desc: Monster Hunt 2 is gorgeous to look at but its weak storyline exists merely to set up tiresome shenanigans that will appeal largely to its core audience of children.

name: Basmati Blues
desc: A musical with it’s heart in the right place but execution and dance numbers spread all over like an automobile accident in the paddy fields.

name: Midnight Sun
desc: Midnight Sun is an unimaginative copy of all the popular films in the genre. The only takeaway from this film is a disease — Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP) and that’s not what you expect from it.

name: A Quiet Place
desc: An intriguing premise makes ‘A Quiet Place’ an essential horror flick because of its understanding of the genre, and a cast that absorbs you into their terrifying world.

name: Ready Player One
desc: Hypnotic immersive entertainment at its best, Ready Player One is classic Spielberg returning to his top form. A Sci-fi film with a heart, not once does Spielberg’s passion for creating spectacular cinematic movie-going experience, overshadow his story’s underlying message – technology can never replace human emotions.

name: Pacific Rim: Uprising
desc: Devoid of the heart and soul of its predecessor, ‘Pacific Rim: Uprising’ aims to please hardcore fans of massive monster versus robot fights, and does a fine job of it.

name: Gringo
desc: ‘Gringo’ is far from groundbreaking, but it’s a fun watch with enough twists and turns to put some Bollywood masala potboilers to shame.

name: The Square
desc: ‘The Square’ is an out-of-the-box dark comedy that will either leave you wondering what you witnessed or make you question the principles you choose to live by.

name: The Hurricane Heist
desc: More than just a regular ‘save the earth’ film, this one combines an offbeat plot with some decent special effects to make it an interesting watch.

name: Tomb Raider
desc: ‘Tomb Raider’ suffers from the tropes of an origin tale, but gives its protagonist a timely and relevant overhaul to confidently launch Alicia Vikander as this generation’s Lara Croft.

name: The Valley
desc: A darkly poignant film on the subject of loss, depression and how people deal with life when faced with such difficulties.

name: Red Sparrow
desc: A torture porn with the sensibility of a 50 Shades… like erotic fantasy, Red Sparrow fails to take flight as the chilling spy thriller, you’d expect it to be.

name: Lady Bird
desc: Awkward, hilarious and bittersweet, ‘Lady Bird’ is one of Hollywood’s most original and refreshingly honest films about growing up.

name: Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri
desc: An unassuming film that surprises you with its provocative subject matter and evocative performances that are hard to forget.

name: Hostiles
desc: Despite gorgeous cinematography, riveting moments of action & drama, and great performances by Bale & Pike, ‘Hostiles’ misses the mark by giving us just an overview of its real subject matter.

name: The Shape Of Water
desc: This enchanting fairy-tale with a hint of realism, is an exquisite piece of cinema that compels you to believe in miracles.

name: Black Panther
desc: Writer-director Ryan Coogler’s robust screenplay showcases strong women and compelling villains to make King T’Challa – the ‘Black Panther’ – a valuable and essential addition to Marvel’s superhero stable.

name: Den Of Thieves
desc: The film solely works in portions where the semi-ambiguous writing makes you wonder if there’s more to the story than meets the eye.

name: Maze Runner: The Death Cure
desc: If you’re a fan of the franchise, enjoy watching ‘save the world from the apocalypse’ type of action thrillers and have been following the story over the years, this finale might be of interest to you.

name: Phantom Thread
desc: The challenging but intriguing Phantom Thread is another beautifully crafted work of art by Paul Thomas Anderson, with a masterful score that accompanies the unique characters played by a strong cast.

name: Darkest Hour
desc: ‘Darkest Hour’ is pretentiously flawed in its obvious award-baiting, but well produced and rousing enough thanks to Gary Oldman in one of his most impressive performances.

name: Paddington 2
desc: Funnier, more charming and heartwarming than the original, ‘Paddington 2’ is the quintessential feel-good animated movie for kids of all ages.

name: The Post
desc: ‘The Post’ is a powerhouse of acting talent led by Streep and Hanks, as Spielberg creates a timely, relevant, and inspiring film through classic storytelling.

name: Insidious: The Last Key
desc: If you are looking for some spine-chilling thrills and a well-made horror mystery, please look ‘further’. The Last Key is more of a final nail in the coffin for the Insidious series.

name: All The Money In The World
desc: Ridley Scott’s uneven pacing and tonality might be a detrimental factor to those expecting a taut thriller but a great performance by Christopher Plummer makes it worthwhile.

name: The Greatest Showman
desc: The beauty of The Greatest Showman is not limited to its visual appeal – spectacular sets, acrobatic performances, dances and singing ability of its artistes, it touches upon social issues like class discrimination or aversion towards human abnormalities that continue to plague our society even today.

name: Hare Krishna! The Mantra, The Movement And The Swami Who Started It All
desc: An interesting documentary at how an Indian religious movement got acceptance as well as some amount of notoriety in the West.

name: Ferdinand
desc: A fun film that doesn’t just put a smile on your face but also leaves a message — you don’t have to do things just because others expect you to.

name: Star Wars: The Last Jedi
desc: An emotionally rewarding tale with all the essential standout moments expected from a Star Wars movie, ‘The Last Jedi’ has its own unique voice that propels the series in an unexpected direction.

name: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House
desc: The textbook definition of a missed opportunity, ‘Mark Felt’ is a tedious political thriller despite its talented, reputable cast.

name: Borg McEnroe
desc: Janus Metz’s biopic is a nerve-racking five-setter that leaves you gasping for breath. Like a classic centre court final, this tense and thrilling sports drama heads to a nail-biting climax, thus evoking unprecedented attention throughout.

name: Anna Karenina: Vronsky's Story
desc: If costume dramas of yore are your thing then you might want to catch the film at a theatre near you. But, if you are looking for an engaging adaptation of the book, then skip this one.

name: Finders Keepers
desc: While the makers have tried to milk the script, as a viewer you will be only keeping a close look at your watch and pray that this hair-brained comedy will be over soon.

name: Wonder
desc: Well-balanced, extremely relevant and combined with a strong message, 'Wonder' is a wholesome family entertainer that is worth your time.

name: Murder on the Orient Express
desc: Despite the glitches and avalanches, thanks to a stellar cast and gripping source material, this mysterious train journey is worth taking.

name: Coco
desc: Disney-Pixar reminds us that it still hasn’t lost its touch in ‘Coco’. Take your kids along for it, and if you don’t have any, don’t hesitate to go alone!

name: Thank You For Your Service
desc: While war films aren’t always everyone’s cup of tea, thanks to their (usually) dramatic storyline, this one’s worth a watch if you’re in the mood for something serious.

name: Justice League
desc: The course-correction feel is glaringly obvious, but ‘Justice League’ is made for the fans, and if you’re one, you’ll have a lot of fun.

name: My Little Pony
desc: My Little Pony is a English movie released on 6 Oct, 2017. The movie is directed by Jayson Thiessen and  featured Tara Strong,  Kristin Chenoweth,  Emily Blunt and  Ashleigh Ball as lead characters. Other popular actors who were roped in for My Little Pony are  Andrea Libman and  Cathy Weseluck

name: A Bad Moms Christmas
desc: With only a few occasional laughs, ‘A Bad Moms Christmas’ ends up being yet another generic Christmas flick with crude sexual innuendo and ample genital anatomy gags to justify the ‘bad’ in the title.

name: Loving Vincent
desc: Although ‘Loving Vincent’ will remain a significant cinematic achievement for a while, its visually compelling artwork is hindered by slow pacing & conjecture.

name: Geostorm
desc: A world-wide net of interconnected satellites installed to save the planet from storms fails and starts attacking the world instead and humanity has precious few hours left to save itself from the storm of biblical proportions.

name: Thor: Ragnarok
desc: Filled from start to finish with its own quirky flavor, ‘Thor: Ragnarok’ is another entry from Marvel you simply cannot miss!

name: Victoria & Abdul
desc: Despite an uneven narrative and historical inaccuracies, Victoria and Abdul is a delightful film that deserves to be watched for Judi Dench.

name: The LEGO Ninjago Movie (3D)
desc: This isn’t a piece of typical animation fluff. It’s a delightful film that rides on wry humour and caters to all age groups, of course, mostly children.

name: Blade Runner 2049
desc: ‘Blade Runner 2049’ is a rare sequel helmed by a masterful storyteller that manages to enhance the original by making all the questions raised there even more relevant today.

name: Kingsman: The Golden Circle
desc: As long as you don’t expect it to be a genre-defying blockbuster as its predecessor – get comfortable and enjoy ‘The Golden Circle’ for the same tongue-in-cheek humour and gritty action starring a cast of well-known names.

name: Terminator 2: Judgment Day 3D
desc: Often imitated, never duplicated – ‘T2’ is an unmissable action blockbuster landmark that is still extremely relevant and enjoyable today!

name: The Nut Job 2: Nutty by Nature
desc: The film has its moments but not enough to deserve a big screen viewing, unless you are obsessed with talkative squirrels.

name: It
desc: Bone-chilling yet endearing, this Stephen King adaptation stays true to the novel while possibly invoking a fear of clowns in a whole new generation.

name: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth to Power
desc: The documentary works wonderfully as a primer for the unaware and will reinforce the need for swift action for the ones in the know.

name: The Hitman's Bodyguard
desc: Solid performances from the cast, especially the lead pair, overshadow the uneven tonality and length of Hitman's Bodyguard to make it a fun if forgettable watch.

name: The Emoji Movie
desc: ‘Embrace yourself just the way you are and why fit in when you can stand out?’ is the message that lies at the heart of this digital tale

name: Atomic Blonde
desc: With gripping action sequences and stylish fun, 'Atomic Blonde' lays down the foundation for a new spy-driven franchise

name: Valerian and The City of A Thousand Planets
The Black Prince
desc: The Black Prince is the agonising true tale of Duleep Singh, the last Sikh king of Punjab, who was robbed off his mother, Kingdom, faith and lineage by the British.

name: Dunkirk
desc: 'Dunkirk' is another landmark achievement by one of the most important and skilled storytellers in the present generation of filmmaking.

name: War For The Planet Of The Apes
desc: A thought-provoking and emotionally resonant film that balances action and special effects to make it the strongest entry in the 'Planet of the Apes' franchise.

name: Spider-Man: Homecoming
desc: Spider-Man: Homecoming breathes new life into the friendly neighbourhood superhero that was forever torn between love and responsibility.

name: The Big Sick
desc: The film lacks the vitality of My Big Fat Greek Wedding and other such immigrant romcoms and could most certainly do with a 10-minute shorter run.

name: Baby Driver
desc: Baby Driver is just that. A triumph. For its sheer originality in execution and a cast of cool-cats capable of charming your socks off.

name: Despicable Me 3
desc: Though lacking the warmth of the original, if you don't mind too many Grus, guns, bubblegums and robots, this colourful, cutesy film can be a fun one time watch.

name: All Eyez on Me
desc: It's an authorised biopic of the slain rapper Tupac Shakur leading from the time he got famous until his violent death

name: The Mummy
desc: This franchise-building reboot is a shoddy stab at merging standard Tom Cruise action along with mythology, horror and comedy.

name: A Death In The Gunj
desc: A Death In The Gunj will make you drop your jaw several times, except for the one time you'd really want it to: the climax.

name: Wonder Woman
desc: ‘Wonder Woman’ is a blend of an uplifting & humorous outlook with strong female characters, that does justice to the iconic female superhero.

name: The Lost City of Z
desc: Memorable scenes and inspired performances are thrown off by clunky editing to make ‘The Lost City of Z’ an unbalanced, but fascinating watch.

name: Pirates Of The Caribbean: Salazar’s Revenge
Everything, Everything
desc: Everything, Everything certainly isn’t what epic, heart-wrenching love stories are made of, but it’ll do as a date-movie that doesn’t demand everything of you.

name: King Arthur: Legend of the Sword (3D)
desc: Despite the inconsistency in pace and vision behind this unique take on the legend of Arthur, Ritchie pulls it off in style.

name: Alien: Covenant
desc: A rehash of several elements that made the series work, 'Alien: Covenant' does little to propel it into compelling territory.

name: Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2
desc: Arguably the most vibrant and whimsical comic book film we’ve seen in a while, ‘Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2’ shows us why they are such a big deal on a cosmic level.

name: Unforgettable
desc: Unforgettable looks like a half-hearted attempt at adapting The Hand That Rocks The Cradle and for a thriller, plays it too safe.

name: The Zookeeper's Wife
desc: The film is a poignant, true tale of survival that unfolded at the Warsaw Zoo during Germany’s invasion of Poland in the Second World War.

name: Sonata
desc: In Sonata, a movie adaptation of Mahesh Elkunchwar’s play, Sen casually invites us into the lives of three women in the their sunset years.

name: Aftermath
desc: Aftermath, with its promising premise, could have been an intense drama but what you get instead is a wandering, forgettable story that reeks of nothingness.

name: Fast & Furious 8
desc: Fast and Furious 8 doesn't break new ground, but makes it up by destroying a whole lot of cars and bones along the way.

name: Ghost In The Shell
desc: This modern revision inspired by the iconic anime is visually arresting but thematically doesn’t progress beyond a dumbed down origin tale.

name: Chips
desc: A formulaic film, there are no real surprises here and it fails to cash in its chips as far as holding your interest is concerned.

name: Life
desc: ‘Life’ is a tautly wound thriller that does little to change the scope of the genre but enough to keep you on the edge of your seat.

name: Beauty and the Beast
desc: This is a live-action remake of Disney’s classic love story. ‘Beauty lies within’ is what an enchantress expects a vain and arrogant prince (Dan Stevens) to know.

name: Kong: Skull Island (3D)
desc: While this instalment tries to match up to Peter Jackson's 2005 adventure, it lacks its epic cinematic moments, like Kong scaling the Empire State building.

name: Patriots Day
desc: If you have lived in Mumbai or any city in the world that has been a soft target of terrorists, you won’t be able to hold back your tears while watching this emotional thriller.

name: Logan
desc: What makes the movie different from other superhero flicks is the way director James Mangold has dealt with the subject — without hesitating to show his ageing superheroes go into battle while they fight their own inner demons.

name: Guardians — The Superheroes
desc: Take a bowlful of The Avengers, add a teaspoon of the Fantastic Four and sprinkle some X-Men superpowers for taste. And voila! You have Guardians The Superheroes.

name: Split
desc: Shyamalan takes a calculated risk with ‘Split’ that pays off largely due to a gripping story, and a memorable performance by McAvoy.

name: Hidden Figures
desc: Hidden Figures is the incredible story about three extraordinary coloured women-mathematicians who overcome gender and race bias to make space history.

name: John Wick: Chapter 2
desc: It might not do much to your brain, but it'll certainly set your heart racing. If you’re in the mood for blood, Wick is your pick.

name: The Space Between Us
desc: In ‘The Space Between Us’, the real space ends up being between a great concept on paper, and its actualisation on screen.

name: Resident Evil: The Final Chapter
desc: Leaner than the previous installments, this film has Alice (Milla Jovovich) has a mission to save the remaining 4,500 people

name: The Founder
desc: This business drama falls short of being a powerful biopic but if you are a loyal customer of McDonald’s, a budding businessman or a Michael Keaton fan, you’ll like it.

name: The Crew 3D
desc: Top-notch effects and an uncompromising second half puts 'The Crew' on par with some of the best action-disaster flicks.

name: The Bye Bye Man
desc: The Bye Bye Man starts out interestingly enough, but quickly jumps genres from college-horror to cheesy slasher film.

name: Friend Request
desc: A popular college student unfriends an unknown girl on a social media website which unleashes a demonic entity that endangers all her friends and family.

name: Allied
desc: This is certainly not a classic like the yesteryear Casablanca, yet if story-telling and subtle performances do it for you, give it a shot.

name: Passengers
desc: It’s a great-looking film with an original idea. Watch it for its stars but it won’t have an astronomical impact on you.

name: Assassin's Creed
desc: Hollywood simply can't make the transition from console to cinema as the movie squanders the considerable talents of its cast and crew.

name: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story
Office Christmas Party
desc: This comedy trades genuine laugh-out-loud moments for far-fetched shenanigans with the intent of putting an emphatic ‘X’ in Xmas.

name: Underworld: Blood Wars
desc: Blood Wars is no less gory, but the fight choreography feels exhausting and it’s made worse with choppy editing that barely allows for anything of merit to register on screen.

name: Arrival
desc: Don't let the deliberate pacing dissuade you; ‘Arrival’ makes you ponder the implications of time, love, life, and death, and the co-relation between communication and the human experience

name: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them
desc: All in all, audiences new and old alike are treated to an endearing adventure with the promise of more to come from J.K. Rowling.

name: Shut In
desc: Mary Portman (Naomi Watts), a widowed psychologist, shuts herself in her house to take care of her disabled 19-year-old son (Charlie Heaton).

name: Desierto
desc: A group of Mexicans cross over the border to the US illegally, but run into a psychotic killer, who doesn’t want immigrants to step foot in his country.

name: Billy Lynn's Long Halftime Walk
desc: Based on Ben Fountain’s 2012 novel, the satirical war drama revolves around the victory tour of 19-year-old Billy Lynn and his troop — members of US Army’s Bravo squad,

name: Mr. Church
desc: The victory of the film lies in the fact that though so many of his facets are revealed, Mr. Church still continues to remain an enigma.

name: Trolls
desc: Trolls is a fail-safe film that young parents can take their kids to, and hopefully enjoy a few chuckles themselves.

name: Doctor Strange
desc: In a stroke of casting genius, Benedict Cumberbatch embodies Dr. Stephen Strange, who not only looks the part, but also embraces the quirkiness of the character.

name: Train To Busan
desc: 'Train to Busan’ is a thoroughly enjoyable, and occasionally thought-provoking experience, making it a must-watch for horror fans!

name: Inferno
desc: Despite a few flaws, Ron Howard’s film is a competent adaptation and offers mild cerebral entertainment that manages to engage you.

name: The Girl On The Train
desc: The film adaptation of Paula Hawkins' bestselling novel by the same name revolves around Rachel (Emily Blunt), an alcoholic divorcee, who finds solace in the ‘perfect couple’ - Megan (Haley Bennett) and Scott (Luke Evans).

name: Miss Peregrine's Home For Peculiar Children
Storks
desc: Storks is a perfectly serviceable means of entertainment for small kids with animation that is appealing to the eye without coming across as being too gaudy or overdone.

name: The Magnificent Seven
desc: The classic story of The Magnificent Seven – based on the 1960 movie that was in turn based on Akira Kurosawa's 1954 Japanese-language film Seven Samurai – gets a modern retelling with a cool star cast.

name: Robinson Crusoe
desc: Robinson Crusoe has its share of action and the brisk pace does help. The animal and bird characters are no doubt lovely to watch. The sight gags and snappy one-liners will also elicit a few laughs from children.

name: The Shallows
desc: Nancy Adams' dream holiday turns into a nightmare when she finds herself in the feeding grounds of a great white shark.

name: Don't Breathe
desc: Right from the opening frame, ​​Don’t Breathe gets into the heart of things with an ominous scene that looks straight out of a nightmare.

name: Nine Lives
desc: The film essentially rides on the humour, Spacey’s dry wit and wry asides, as he at first struggles to come to terms that he is now a cat.

name: Mechanic: Resurrection
desc: For even a seasoned critic or a cynic looking for points to poke about, there are none in the performance that he delivers when it comes to brute action.

name: War Dogs
desc: War Dogs is a telling statement about the shadowy and murky world – albeit a dollar-drenched one fraught with risk and danger at every turn – of arms contractors and subcontractors who facilitate the running of the global war machine.

name: Jason Bourne
desc: Greengrass recreates the quintessential Bourne action replete with high octane chase sequences, fist fights, but you miss Jason Bourne’s enigmatic swag and vulnerability.

name: Ghostbusters
desc: Despite the title, and much like the original, this film doesn’t even pretend to be even anything remotely spooky. Instead, it comes across more as a nearly two-hour long joke reel that never takes itself too seriously.

name: Bad Moms
desc: It gets too much with Bad Moms, for them in time and so, they decide to take charge of their lives again. Rediscovering happiness and a sense of self-satisfaction.

name: Lights Out
desc: This film continues the new trend of horror films going away from the tried and tested found footage and haunted house tropes.

name: Star Trek Beyond
desc: The Federation is experiencing a new era of prosperity and inter-planetary peace and has even constructed a giant new Starbase, the Yorktown.

name: Ice Age: Collision Course
desc: Collision Course is a relentless, fun-filled, fast-paced and most recent part in a long-running series that is pretty much sure to keep the kids (the audience for this movie) entertained with its energy

name: Free State of Jones
desc: The film has all the makings of a fascinating drama but the half-baked plot turns to be too problematic. Trimmer editing and ingenious writing could have earned this one a cult status.

name: Independence Day: Resurgence
desc: If you enjoy formulaic chaos and are fine with cliched celebration of human resilience, this one's quite engaging. We wish there was at least one iconic scene though.

name: Finding Dory
desc: A classic Pixar movie, Finding Dory is all heart. Baby Dory, with eyes that can melt your heart, drifts away from her parents when a current sucks her away.

name: Warcraft
desc: Despite the sincerity, the film suffers from the lack of a solid screenplay, which is silly in parts with a persistent stale feel to it.

name: Me Before You
desc: Jojo Moyes’ tearjerker novel by the same name tells the touching love story of two unlikely people who make the emotional journey from being strangers to soulmates.

name: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows
The Nice Guys
desc: Replete with nudity and violence, if eccentric crime dramas with a dash of dark comedy are up your street, The Nice Guys is your film.

name: Alice Through The Looking Glass
desc: When compared to Burton's work, this one pales in comparison. If you haven't seen his film, you are bound to find this wondrous, a journey worth taking for sure.

name: The Angry Birds Movie
desc: The birds are cute, but an unambitious storytelling sans twists and turns, makes this bird-watching unexciting if not tedious.

name: X-Men: Apocalypse
desc: The baddies are not menacing enough, especially Apocalypse, whose undefined powerful persona runs out of steam. This is strictly for the fans!

name: Criminal
desc: It might seem needlessly gratuitous at times but you can let that slip as you’ve probably not seen Costner in this challenging a role (for him at least) in quite a while.

name: Money Monster
desc: Watch this one. It is more than just a hostage-crisis film. It tries hard to make you think about the bigger picture, and mostly succeeds.

name: Pele: Birth of A Legend
desc: The movie’s trajectory is also a bit predictable and you should know that this film focuses quite squarely on his early life. What can bog the film down at times though is that it can get a bit heavy-handed.

name: My Big Fat Greek Wedding 2
desc: My Big Fat Greek Wedding 2 does have a distinct sitcom-like feel to it. You can almost imagine this concept being stretched into several seasons, mined with gags galore.

name: Captain America: Civil War
desc: Without giving away anything that might spoil this treat for Marvel and superhero fans, let’s just say that Captain America: Civil War is essentially like a battle royale between superheroes like you’ve never seen before.

name: 10 Cloverfield Lane
desc: Winstead's performance is also amazing, evoking both empathy and intensity with equal ease. Don’t miss this gem of a thriller.

name: The Man Who Knew Infinity
desc: Brown also tries to give the story an emotional touch, to good effect. And in fact, it is this which makes this film both enjoyable and gripping.

name: Mother’s Day
desc: All said and done, the two strongest points of this film would basically be Julia Roberts and a bit of slapstick humour.

name: The Huntsman: Winter’s War
desc: In ping-ponging in between the sibling rivalry and the love story, the narrative fails to get too deep into either track. All said and done though, it’s the visual dazzle that keeps this one afloat.

name: The Jungle Book
desc: More than anything, the intricate landscaping, masterful camerawork and environment (actually filmed in Downtown Los Angeles) create a delightfully immersive experience. Heartwarming and enjoyable.

name: Kung Fu Panda 3
desc: Kung Fu Panda 3 by and large hits the right notes by serving up everything that fans of this franchise have loved, while adding some new elements too.

name: The Divergent Series: Allegiant
desc: While the previous film in this series set the stage for a hopefully interesting follow up, Allegiant turns out to be a bit of a letdown.

name: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice
Norm Of The North
desc: In an age where even animated flicks are designed for consumption for the junior and senior of our species, this film somehow manages to take the intelligence of children for granted.

name: Bus 657
desc: Bus 657 is a fairly fast-paced cat-and-mouse chase involving the said casino thieves trying to outrun both the mob as well as the cops, who are in hot pursuit.

name: The Program
desc: It’s hard to shake off the feeling that the film feels a bit inconsistent or too rushed, like a retelling in quick time of an elaborate scam that could have been examined in more detail.

name: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi
desc: While this film is unabashedly patriotic (you will inevitably be reminded of American Sniper and Lone Survivor), what works here is Bay’s sense of restraint.

name: 45 Years
desc: The direction and screenplay (intertitles are used) is understated, but younger viewers might find themselves stifling a yawn or two at times.

name: Gods of Egypt
desc: If kitsch mythology and a swords-and-sandals clad Butler along with various bosomy lasses float your boat, it’s passable.

name: The Revenant
desc: From the first frame, you know you’re in for something special and it’s pretty clear that Leonardo has given his everything to this film.

name: How To Be Single
desc: By and large though, the movie puts the spotlight on how complicated the dating scenario – at least for some people – can be in contemporary times.

name: The Choice
desc: As a viewer that can engage you about this movie in terms of emotional content. Yes, there are babes in two-piece bikinis frolicking around a bit but that does not a movie make. And it is lame.

name: The Finest Hours
desc: What really works for Finest Hours is the way Gillespie and the effects team recreate the sound and fury of the stormy sea.

name: Room
desc: Those who want to see something fast-paced will find themselves in the wrong cinema hall. But if you just open your mind and let yourself be immersed in this narrative, you might find a few rewards.

name: The Boy
desc: The suspense thriller has a striking beginning and a solid setting. However, static pace and generic mystery play spoilers.

name: Asterix: The Mansions of the Gods
Joy
desc: Heartbreaking, uplifting, liberating...Joy makes you instill faith in your abilities once again. It has that ‘The Pursuit of Happyness’ (2006) feel to it.

name: The 5th Wave
desc: The film comes across as an under-whelming fan tribute to Twilight and The Hunger Games series. Watch 'other' films instead.

name: Alvin And The Chipmunks-The Road Chip
The Hateful Eight
desc: Tarantino’s cinema is not for the faint-hearted.  However, the maker of Reservoir Dogs and Kill Bill, in his by now famous signature style, once again gives you substance to lose sleep over.

name: Daddy's Home
desc: While it seems entertaining at the beginning, the film ends up being forgettable, uninspired, done-to-death, formulaic comedy.

name: Our Brand Is Crisis
desc: As a film about a woman embarking on the path of self-discovery, caught between marketing and the media, the film works. As a tale on political one-upmanship, it doesn’t.

name: Monster Hunt
desc: Monster Hunt, although an acquired taste, is an interestingly different tale told keeping various  Chinese themes in mind, in addition to various sight gags, martial arts (but of course) and some humour too.

name: Point Break
desc: Although this is a remake of 1991’s 'Point Break,' this version often takes off on its own tangent but with a substantially-increased action quotient.

name: Snoopy and Charlie Brown - The Peanuts Movie
Everly
desc: If you’re a diehard Salma Hayek fan and want to see her in a role she’s probably never done before, you’ll get that here too.

name: In The Heart Of The Sea
Creed
desc: Simply put, if you like films about boxing, with the emotional quotient thrown in, you will enjoy this one. It’s Stallone, after all.

name: The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 2
desc: What makes this film more exciting than the previous installments in this series is that there’s a lot of action, a few scares and plenty of thrills to keep fans of this franchise well entertained.

name: Spectre
desc: Spectre is one of Bond's most thrilling action movies - but also one of his most ghostly, reaching into an eerie past.

name: Secret In Their Eyes
desc: The story is told with generous use of flashbacks, which makes it essential to watch this film with a fair degree of concentration. All in all, a fairly gripping tale.

name: ​Paranormal Activity: The Ghost Dimension
desc: In any event, the scares only happen at the very end. All in all, Ghost Dimension does not really deliver the excitement that horror film fans seek.

name: Goosebumps
desc: The film, with the well-mounted CG villains - the werewolf, the abominable snowman, body squeezers - and its hair-raising playfulness, is a pleasure ride.

name: Rock The Kasbah
desc: While the film’s basic premise is unusual and in parts interesting, it loses steam in the second half, with a fairly bland conclusion.

name: The Last Witch Hunter
desc: The special effects are noteworthy and then of course, there are Vin Diesel’s heroics, which comprise the two reasons why you’d probably watch this one.

name: Crimson Peak
desc: There’s plenty of doom and Gothic gloom in here but at its heart, this is a beautiful story (albeit a rather unusual one) of courage, and love.

name: The Walk
desc: The final 40 minutes of the film, really suits the 3D treatment, makes it all worthwhile. Delightfully quaint and definitely entertaining.

name: The Martian
desc: In Watney’s iconic style, it’s about ‘scienceing the sh** out of” your nightmares. His unflinching determination and persistence to survive is a story you don’t want to miss. Go for it.

name: The Intern
desc: The Intern is a generational matchup of Baby Boomer-meets-millennial mindset with the office as a backdrop. You’ll watch it for De Niro and Hathaway’s easy onscreen chemistry.

name: Everest
desc: While the film can drag at times, emphasis is placed on the man-versus-nature angle here. An interesting tale of tragedy and survival.

name: We Are Your Friends
desc: This story is far too simplistic, the characters unevenly explained and too many corners are cut. Simply put, you’ll watch it if you’re big fan of Efron or Ratajkowski.

name: Hitman: Agent 47
desc: The action is slick and indeed, very stylish. Don’t expect much from the script; you don’t watch a movie like Hitman while expecting Shakespearian prose delivered as shots are fired.

name: She's Funny That Way
desc: She's Funny That Way is a charming little film which benefits from its quaint milieu. Peter Bogdanovich weaves in the element of simplicity and affability.

name: Ricki and the Flash
desc: Streep’s presence in Ricki elevates what could have been a fairly ordinary family drama into something that is refreshingly different.

name: Fantastic Four
desc: The script is dull, littered with clichéd catchphrases and humorless. There are barely any action scenes in the film, save the film’s climax, which looks rushed.

name: The Gift
desc: If you enjoy psych-thrillers, there will be plenty to think about long after the end credits have rolled. Do not miss this one.

name: The Vatican Tapes
desc: While there are a few scary scenes, the overall feeling is that Neveldine could have served up far more terrifying film if he’d pushed the envelope more, given the intense subject matter.

name: Southpaw
desc: Though laden with clichés, it is consistently hard-hitting and never loses plot. The right blend of heart and skill works in suffusing an operatic feel to the movie which is an absolute knockout.

name: Mr. Holmes
desc: The philosophy of this tale, inspired by the novel A Slight Trick of the Mind, charms. Alongside wonderful acting, the cinematography captures an enchantingly pretty country.

name: Ant-Man
desc: Reed and team have crafted a superhero film that is not only action-packed (not excessively so), but also funny and thankfully devoid of bluster. At its heart though, this is a heist movie.

name: The Gallows
desc: There has been a clutch of films since then that serve up cinematic variations of found footage fare. Some work, some don’t. The Gallows lies somewhere in between.

name: Amy
desc: If you’re a fan of Amy Winehouse's music, you wouldn't want to miss this. The singer may be gone but the songs thankfully, live on.

name: Terminator Genisys
desc: Terminator Genisys overhauls the franchise that made the phrase ‘I’ll be back’ a part of pop culture. More than anything, you’ll watch it for Arnold.

name: Child 44
desc: If you do decide to watch this film, it will be to check out the kind of realism that Tom Hardy brings to his character.

name: Insidious: Chapter 3
desc: The prequel to the successful horror series is helmed by a new director this time around, bringing you a mixed bag of treats, or scares, to be more appropriate.

name: Inside Out
desc: Inside Out can be enjoyed by a variety of age groups and is both nuanced and sensitive without sacrificing the fun angle.

name: Entourage
desc: You might on one hand, find the main characters a bit too breezy, but those familiar with the various seasons of the show will find all of what they see to be reassuringly familiar and fun.

name: Jurassic World
desc: The effects are superb, the action is supersized and ultimately, if there is just one word that can describe this movie, that word would be ‘awesome’.

name: The Duff
desc: Despite the very predictable way the movie moves along, the message here is simple – that if someone loves you, they will do so because of who you really are on the inside.

name: The Age of Adaline
desc: Apart from an ending that seemed a tad stretched and the voiceovers that were unnecessary, this is an unusual and engaging saga of everlasting love.

name: What We Did On Our Holiday
desc: It’s paced pretty nicely, helped along with an at times tart and mostly witty script, with the director duo having writing credits too. Pike is nothing short of charming, as is indeed, the film.

name: San Andreas
desc: Watch this one with minimal hopes, keeping intact a neutral approach. San Andreas despite its weak plot and improper timing, has its exhilarating moments and is definitely worth a watch.

name: Maggie
desc: The film straddles a sort of middle ground between scary and family drama and it takes a look at the other side of a zombie film – the human side sans violence.

name: Tomorrowland
desc: There’s plenty for kids to enjoy – laser guns, jet packs, space ships and plenty of tricks to fire a fertile imagination. At the same time, it also manages to mix in a message about environmentalism.

name: Big Game
desc: The film's picturesque setting, exaggerated lines and well-drawn action sequences are fun while it lasts but not compelling enough to desire a repeat.

name: Danny Collins
desc: This one is Al Pacino all the way – his panache, style, energy and fluidity will move and delight you. And hey, you get to hear him croon as well.

name: Playing It Cool
desc: While the romance element clicks, the film doesn't quite work as a comedy. A few one-liners do make you giggle, but that's that.

name: Hot Pursuit
desc: Hot Pursuit is a film that takes the whole buddy-movie formula and gives it a wild, sometimes boisterous and genuinely funny female spin.

name: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water
desc: The screenwriters were having a ball as the film is full of unexplained randomness. It works, more so because of the tight editing and economical run-time.

name: Avengers: Age of Ultron
desc: If Avengers was a biryani, with all the flavours coming together seamlessly, AOU is a desi thaali, full of scrumptious dishes, but a tad in excess. It's spectacular, yet can leave you exhausted.

name: The Water Diviner
desc: Crowe’s undeniable screen presence adds gravity to the film and he manages to make you empathize with his grief and the doggedness of his search, against all odds.

name: Broken Horses
desc: There are a few moments of unnecessarily heightened melodrama and if anything, we would have liked to have seen more consistency when it comes to the grittiness and dark edges.

name: Home
desc: Home is meant squarely for kids, but that doesn't mean that accompanying adults will also not find this multi-coloured tale of the importance of friendship and familial bonds, heartwarming.

name: Fast And Furious 7
desc: Furious 7 has a humane angle. The touching tribute to Walker puts the entire series into perspective and will make many eyes teary.

name: The Gunman
desc: The fight scenes are unsparing, offering gore galore in graphic detail. Therefore, you'll only want to see this is if the sound of gunfire is music to your ears.

name: Run All Night
desc: There's plenty of atmosphere to boot, thanks to cinematographer Martin Ruhe's interesting use of quadrants in his framing technique, adding to the movie's general sense of urgency.

name: Dragon Blade
desc: Of all of Jackie Chan’s recent escapades, this is the only one that not only lives up to his desired ambitious streak but also has a warm touch to it.

name: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel
desc: This is a fun story with as many layers as a Jaipuri pagdi. The acting is such fun that you appreciate characters, even if you didn't check into the first Hotel.

name: Chappie
desc: As a movie, Chappie is slightly bonkers (Jackman in cargo shorts, humans babying a robot, Copleyâ€™s voice intonations for his character, etc), but delightfully so.

name: The Lazarus Effect
desc: Love, longing, tears, everlasting friendship...to watch the film in 3D is to live it. The dragons give you wings! They fly, you fly.

name: Against The Sun
desc: It is quite a challenge to keep a film that only involves three men, a raft and the open ocean engaging and involving. Definitely an inspirational tale.

name: Whiplash
desc: When the thumping tom-toms, trombones and tympani fall silent, what you are also left with is a career-topping performance (thus far, at least!) from Miles Teller.

name: Wild
desc: While the ending seems a bit hurried and underwhelming, it is Witherspoon who shines throughout. She is extremely convincing in this stripped-down role.

name: Mr. Turner
desc: Apart from the fantastic characterizations and top-notch cinematography, the real beauty of Turner’s vision was his ability to find beauty in the seemingly ordinary.

name: Wild Card
desc: With an unsurprising climax, weak story and repetitive action, the film fails to be half as good as a regular Statham gag must mandatorily be.

name: The Boy Next Door
desc: Culminating into a horrendously gore-filled climax, this shallow movie offers nothing new and is infuriatingly tiresome to sit through.

name: Foxcatcher
desc: Foxcatcher is aided by a powerful script (Max Frye and Dan Futterman) and is based on a true story. The tale is no doubt an unsettling one… and yet, you’ll not want to miss a second.

name: Seventh Son
desc: To be fair, it’s apparent that the most effort has gone into the visual effects and the battles, which are the two redeeming factors about this film.

name: Mortdecai
desc: The film is paced well but unfortunately, a lot of the jokes fall flat. The film simmers but never really sizzles, despite moments of potential.

name: Paddington
