desc: The seamless blending of animation with live action is the most striking point in the film. The jaunty film score also keeps things moving along rather nicely.

name: American Sniper
desc: American Sniper is hard-hitting, no doubt, and predominantly a performance-oriented film, where Cooper shines. It isn't the Clint Eastwood classic you expect it to be, though.

name: Taken 3
desc: What works greatly to the movie’s credit is the pacing (never a dull moment here!) and that sense of ‘What’s going to happen next?’

name: Big Eyes
desc: The film is largely compelling and touches upon many aspects about the dynamics of a couple’s love, along with the lengths and limits of tolerance one can have for the other.

name: The Woman in Black 2: Angel of Death
desc: The movie doesn’t rewrite the book of shock (despite the jump scares), but what you get is a fast-paced scare flick with an ending that could have been creepier.

name: Unbroken
desc: O’Connell and Ishihara bring a stunning sense of realism to their roles, which is a great reason why you’ll want to watch this movie.

name: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb
desc: This fairly entertaining kiddie comedy is full of funny little asides and exchanges that keep the pace going. Fun viewing for the holidays.

name: The Hobbit: The Battle Of The Five Armies
desc: Everything that fans will expect to see in such a film is in here, times ten. A grandiose end to the three-part saga.

name: Jessabelle
desc: It's the abrupt, illogical ending that spoils the fun. However, if you like unconventional horror films, you can still watch this one on a lonely afternoon.

name: The Babadook
desc: Kent uses ordinary activities (eg bedtime stories) and manages to inject dread into even that innocent activity. Clichés (eg jump-scares) are cleverly replaced with the power of suggestion.

name: This Is Where I Leave You
Penguins of Madagascar
desc: The pace is brisk – frenzied, even – the animation top-notch and the script is full of witticisms, puns and there are jokes aplenty for the kiddies as well as belly-busters for the grown-ups.

name: Dumb and Dumber To
desc: Jim Carrey fans may well rejoice, for the rubber-faced comedian is back, and channelling his entire range of comedic tricks.

name: The Equalizer
desc: The movie's climax in is a bit drawn out but all said and done, Washington and Csokas are thoroughly convincing and if you're an action junkie, you'll surely get your money's worth.

name: John Wick
desc: This revenge film looks slick, stylish and despite its camp story line, keeps you engrossed throughout with a strong impact.

name: Boyhood
desc: Based on a simple premise, the film turns out to be a unique emotional epic, thanks to the director's outstanding execution.

name: Big Hero 6
desc: Big Hero 6 also provides many moments of genuine sweetness. Definitely a delightful film with its heart in the right place.

name: The Best of Me
desc: The film is based on Nicholas Sparks' book, and if you like his concept of an idealistic romance set against the backdrop of beautiful landscapes with melodrama thrown in, The Best of Me is for you.

name: Fury
desc: The film is surprisingly sophisticated in terms of the drama and interplay between all of the characters. Largely devoid of jingoism, the film looks convincingly 'real'.

name: Sex Tape
desc: There's humour in here for sure, but some more of that playful silliness in between the unnecessary bits would have made this a better watch.

name: The Judge
desc: The Judge is a great example of meticulously-crafted character portrayals and a film that carefully builds up each of the main characters over the course of its duration.

name: Dracula Untold
desc: Luke Evans manages, in most parts, to get his teeth into the substance of Count Dracula's legend convincingly enough.

name: What If
desc: Delightful but somewhat un-memorable, the energy of the film lies in the push-pull conflict between the two protagonists handled deftly by Radcliffe and Kazan.

name: Left Behind
desc: The very concept of the Rapture could have been depicted with power and mystery, but instead the opposite is achieved in a film that just looks slapdash.

name: Annabelle
desc: It will give you your money's worth, while not really serving you anything too memorable (or scary) as some of the other, more sinister horror films we've seen in the last few years.

name: Deliver Us From Evil
desc: The film packs in a mixed bag of thrills that is, at times, deeply disturbing by virtue of using the kind of horror tropes that are more psychological than gory.

name: Two Night Stand
desc: While the plot is simple enough, this is, in essence, a pretty candid and contemporary take on young love, with its many colourful details.

name: Dolphin Tale 2
desc: Featuring a few beautiful scenes that will probably warm the heart of the most hardened cynic, Dolphin Tale 2 makes for some wholesome family fare.

name: The Prince
desc: The greatest effort seems to have gone into getting the look of the fight scenes correctly in an otherwise bland film.

name: If I Stay
desc: Chloë Grace Moretz manages to convey some delicate and bittersweet shades of love and romance with a maturity that prevents the movie from becoming a sob-fest.

name: Life of Crime
desc: The film stops short of being something truly memorable but has just the right amount of witty turns, deft plot twists, funny situations and interesting characters.

name: Sin City 2: A Dame To Kill For
desc: With its simple dialogues and also because it is in essence a gorgeous-looking tableaux, enjoy this slick slice of cinema more for its visuals rather than anything else.

name: Step up All In
desc: The film is like a bunch of music videos strung together with a romance angle. You don't go for this movie for scintillating dialogue, but to see them move it like experts on the dance floor.

name: The November Man
desc: A big reason why you might want to see this film is because Pierce Brosnan is in it. And indeed, it is on his able shoulders that this movie rests.

name: The Expendables 3
desc: While the action is indeed high gear, the gore (evidenced in the previous film) is turned down a notch. Nonetheless, it does serve up a decent chunk of old-school action.

name: The Giver
desc: Despite the impressive cast (Taylor Swift has a cameo), performances are uneven. Bridges and Streep stand out but the others are somewhat unconvincing.

name: Into the Storm
desc: If you get your jollies watching houses, cars and even a bunch of passenger planes flung into the air like toys, you might like this.

name: Guardians of the Galaxy
desc: The charming performances, strange characters (don't miss Del Toro as The Collector), spaceships and the 70s soundtrack (a highlight by itself) make this one a heck of an intergalactic romp.

name: Lucy
desc: Lucy may fail to woo the mainstream audience as it doesn't boast an extravagant budget or thrilling special effects. If you are a fan of 'experimental' cinema, you will appreciate this attempt.

name: 22 Jump Street
desc: All the veiled jokes as well as the blatant gags (Hill and Michael Bacall co-write) might even warrant a second viewing. Go for a load of laughs and stay for the end credits.

name: Hercules
desc: The climax could've been better and while the battles scenes aren't as epic as *Gladiator*, the film, along with its sprinkling of tongue-in-cheek lines, makes for a fun watch.

name: The Grand Budapest Hotel
desc: This whimsical tale oozes charm while brisk editing lets you enjoy - but not be overwhelmed by - cakes like mountains and mountains like cakes, chandeliers, perfumed men and Persian pussies.

name: Planes: Fire & Rescue
desc: While the script is full of obvious aircraft metaphors which are funny, it lacks the kind of witticisms that elevate contemporary animated films so that they can be enjoyed by a much wider audience.

name: Begin Again
desc: Decidedly different from super-budget, superhero fare, this one is sometimes sappy but mostly engaging and definitely driven by music.

name: Dawn of the Planet of the Apes
desc: Emotionally intense, deeply absorbing and visually engaging, DOTPOTA is a solid build-up to another sequel. If not anything, you must watch it for Caesar aka motion capture maestro Andy Serkis.

name: The Fault in Our Stars
desc: If you like feel-good, escapist films, this one's not for you. The Fault in Our Stars is one of the most unpretentious tragic love stories told in a heart-warming manner.

name: Transformers: Age of Extinction
desc: Be it fiery photogenic explosions, smashing buildings, mega monster battles and more, there is no doubt that action rules this film.

name: Chef
desc: With food remaining the biggest star of this show, the side dishes also include some family-bonding as well. And the result is a serving of something refreshingly original.

name: Grace of Monaco
desc: Visually, the film looks pretty, no doubt. But that cannot hide the fact that there's barely enough substance to keep a viewer engaged.

name: How to Train Your Dragon 2 (3D)
desc: Love, longing, tears, everlasting friendship...to watch the film in 3D is to live it. The dragons give you wings! They fly, you fly.

name: Edge of Tomorrow
desc: Writer Hiroshi Sakurazaka's story has solid sci-fi credentials and Tom Cruise proves that he still has the chops to pull off mega action movies.

name: The Raid 2
desc: If you enjoy savage, on-screen action that is unabashedly over-the-top and even sometimes borders on pastiche with all the gangster film tropes, don't hesitate to go watch this.

name: X-Men: Days of Future Past
desc: While it assumes viewer familiarity with all the characters, *Days of Future Past* does manage the improbable task of combining almost everything that we love about the X-Men series, in one place.

name: Million Dollar Arm
desc: Based on a true story, it's a film about hope, determination, believing in oneself and the importance of the journey as compared to the destination.

name: The Amazing Spider-Man 2
desc: The action sequences are breathtaking and despite the running time, the film doesn't drag. This Spider-Man serves up both pathos and power.

name: Brick Mansions
desc: The film has a message at its core but the execution is way too simplistic with the actors acting as if they weren't paid. Action buffs can still watch it for the Parkour-infused chase sequences.

name: Son of God
desc: If you want to watch some really good movies inspired by and about the life of Christ, there are plenty of other options you can go for instead.

name: Transcendence
desc: The film is essentially a far-fetched, sometimes muddled, cautionary tale about mankind being taken over by the machines that they themselves have created, albeit with the best of intentions.

name: Oculus
desc: If you find mirrors spooky, stay away. And if you love to check yourself out in the mirror, this low-budget thriller will compel you to think otherwise.

name: Divergent
desc: At the heart of this dystopian tale awash in grays and browns is a lesson about finding one's identity and being at peace with oneself.

name: Captain America: The Winter Soldier
desc: Rogers might not have Batman's toys, Tony Stark's wisecracks or Superman's strength, but he is the most 'human'. This ranks among the finest in the superhero genre.

name: Muppets Most Wanted
desc: There are cameos aplenty in this fun film. And the song sequences are both fun and wacky - two words that sum up this film.

name: Need For Speed
desc: Apart from Paul's promising performance, it's the supercharged cars that tear up the asphalt and steal the show in this one.

name: 3 Days to Kill
desc: Lighthearted while managing to mix a torture scene with a recipe for spaghetti sauce, the film's myriad elements come together with a deft touch, without losing the plot.

name: Battle of the Damned
desc: The film is about as literal as it gets, which is Dolph Lundgren shooting things, zombies and robots along with a lot of randomness.

name: 300: Rise of an Empire
desc: Although you would have seen many action films set during a point of time in history (this one's set in 480 BC), there is plenty in here to keep your attention from start to finish.

name: August: Osage County
desc: A gripping melodrama about the lives of the Westons, who gravitate back to their Oklahoma hometown, the film is about the interpersonal relationships of this family during a crisis situation.

name: Dallas Buyers Club
desc: This is his incredible life story, told with a dash of humour and an empathy-evoking narrative. Brilliant would be an understatement.

name: Non-Stop
desc: If there's a film that is pretty much true to its name, then this one is it. Another variation on the classic theme of a plane hijack, the movie is relentless with not a wasted second.

name: Pompeii
desc: The love story itself is forgettable and cheesy. But that is only incidental compared to what you can watch this movie for - fight scenes and cataclysmic climax, both produced and recreated nicely.

name: The Monuments Men
desc: The film makes a profound point in a subtle way - that the Führer's ambitions if left unchecked would have been world-altering, in the most unsettling of ways.

name: Vampire Academy
desc: If you like campus romances disguised as thrillers, you are bound to be entertained. And if you happen to be a fangirl/fanboy of those good-looking brooding vampires, then you're in for a treat.

name: Rock Paper Dice Enter
desc: The only noteworthy thing about the movie is the concept it started out with - which to be fair, is unique. But despite that, it goes wrong in almost every other department.

name: The LEGO Movie
desc: Novel, wild, irreverent and inventive, this movie is a multicoloured marvel. It takes characters just a few centimetres tall and creates a story like you've never seen before in an animated film.

name: I, Frankenstein
desc: If you want to eat that popcorn and enjoy a horror fantasy, go for it. But if you want to revisit the legend of Frankenstein, watch the 1931 classic again.

name: Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit
desc: For avid fans of espionage thrillers, Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit is modestly watchable. For the rest, wait for something different.

name: American Hustle
desc: Intelligent and good-looking, American Hustle could've lost 20 minutes to deliver an even sharper kick. But otherwise, fun for those who like vibrant humour - that's extremely grey.

name: Carrie
desc: While Carrie begins eerily enough, there is a turning point where the screenplay abandons psychological horror of the kind that Shutter or The Conjuring dish out, and goes for full-gear gore instead.

name: Inside Llewyn Davis
desc: Inside Llewyn Davis is full of clever Coen-isms and the film's soundtrack too is wonderful. This one makes for some compelling viewing.

name: 47 Ronin
desc: The movie mixes many elements, but the overall tapestry looks good. An American-accented Kai amongst hardcore Japanese warriors is not jarring.

name: The Secret Life of Walter Mitty
desc: Although Stiller has acted in far-out films like Zoolander before, this one gives viewers another side to this actor – one who can handle such ambitious films with ease.

name: Walking With Dinosaurs 3D
desc: The biggest letdown is the thin plot and some silly dialogues marring an otherwise decent story. The only thing that works for this film is the successful melding of CGI dinosaurs in live-action.

name: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug
desc: The film is supremely accessible and enjoyable, even if you haven't read Tolkien. This one’s a packed-to-the-gills entertainer from start to finish.

name: Oldboy
desc: The film has graphic violence and perversion, but there is no take-away. It leaves you trying to nail down what the point to this remake really was.

name: The Hunger Games: Catching Fire
desc: Catching Fire is a spectacular ‘edge-of-the-seat’ thriller, which is unnerving, emotionally intense and immensely engaging.

name: Delivery Man
desc: Based on 2011's movie, Starbuck, this is Vaughn's vehicle all the way. All said and done, the movie has its heart in the right place.

name: Battle of the Year
desc: The film's attempt at evoking patriotism (like sports films do) doesn't work at all. No matter how passionate you are for a dance form, to use it in order to arouse nationalism seems futile.

name: Last Vegas
desc: The film is more than just a running gag reel. Due to the brilliance of the actors, Last Vegas offers a sensitive look at the difficulties of old age and the vicissitudes of friendship.

name: Thor: The Dark World
desc: This movie is about sibling rivalry as well as a long-distance love story with an intergalactic twist. Don't miss this one.

name: The Fifth Estate
desc: While the film has a few things going for it, Condon could have scored better if he chose to focus deeper on Assange’s admittedly complex and mysterious psyche.

name: Captain Phillips
desc: This tense drama in the high-seas will leave you feeling claustrophobic. The film is an archetypal Paul Greengrass thriller, which keeps you on the edge of your seat.

name: Escape Plan
desc: The action is routine but the way the characters plan the escape is interesting and inspired. These guys may be old, but they sure know their chops and can still deal the dice, old-school style.

name: About Time
desc: Ultimately, the message is simple and visceral enough to have crossover appeal. Give it a shot if romantic comedies float your boat.

name: Gravity 3D
desc: To sum it up, there are films and then there’s Gravity. For an edge-of-the-seat-rollercoaster-ride experience, watch it only in IMAX 3D.

name: Diana
desc: If you are fine with seeing Diana as the ‘needy’ woman solely looking for love, living in suffocating secrecy, you may like the film.

name: Elysium
desc: Neill Blomkamp, in his inimitable style, gives us a dark science fiction thriller that's relevant to present-day society and existing social and economic inequality.

name: Gambit
desc: This is a fairly standard heist comedy, but is loaded with just enough silly humour and charm to make it a pleasant ride.

name: Prisoners
desc: A film with many emotional components, the visceral panic, desperation and helplessness any parent would feel when their children are abducted, forms its bedrock.

name: Rush
desc: The story-telling lends depth to the characters, leaving you emotionally invested in them. You feel their fear, regrets, insecurities and vulnerability.

name: The Family
desc: Pfeiffer had failed the audition to star opposite De Niro in Martin Scorsese’s Raging Bull. She’s managed it after 30 years and for a movie as good as this, it was totally worth it.

name: 2 Guns
desc: What sets this film apart from standard buddy-cop fare is that the enemy is in their midst and not some larger-than-life despot demanding a ransom the size of a small country's GDP.

name: Grown Ups 2
desc: The only thought that this film might provoke is to make you wonder what Sandler and gang were thinking when they made this.

name: One Direction: This Is Us
desc: Spurlock could have painted a truly gripping, well-rounded picture of a band touring exhaustively. What we get instead is just another staged performance.

name: Riddick
desc: Everything about the film looks as artificial as the glowing-eyes of its central character, barring the cool bikes. Overall, Riddick fails to engage you.

name: Percy Jackson: Sea of Monsters
desc: The best thing about this predictable film is undoubtedly the special effects. For want of anything better, Sea of Monsters is a mishmash of various similar films in this genre.

name: The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones
desc: If you fancy action-fantasies like Underworld, Twilight, Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter and Hansel and Gretel: Witch Hunters, you might like this one.

name: We're the Millers
desc: We're the Millers is a predictable but funny road trip movie that's loaded with sexual expletives. In spite of the occasional silliness, it does make you laugh.

name: The Frozen Ground
desc: The film does navigate through familiar serial killer-thriller checkpoints but the screenplay does pack in some clever tricks.

name: Planes 3D
desc: Planes has its share of fun moments but is underwhelming, especially when compared to the kind of animation films that are being made today.

name: R.I.P.D.
desc: It is an inert, roughly-scripted movie. Despite some zippy camera work and the occasional time-slice photography, it's surprising how plain this big budget ($130 million) film looks.

name: The Conjuring
desc: Director James Wan pulls all the right strings to create an atmosphere so tense and unnerving that if evil spirits feed on your fear, so does the film.

name: The Smurfs 2
desc: All said and done however, while there is nothing disagreeable about this movie, there's nothing very remarkable about it either.

name: The Wolverine
desc: What this film also offers is soul, pathos and a pretty good look at the multifaceted character that is The Wolverine.

name: White House Down
desc: The film has its share of unconvincing moments but if 'One-man-saving-the-world' is your thing and if over-the-top, escapist action is what you seek, White House Down delivers all of that.

name: Pacific Rim
desc: Visuals will have to be this film's calling card because the ballast that holds it back is generic acting, monster film clichés and a sparse script.

name: The Iceman
desc: The film fails to dramatise the character (The Iceman) in order to evoke an audience reaction, which is what is usually expected from crime thrillers.

name: Despicable Me 2
desc: More than anything else, the story has a heart. With the world getting cynical by the day, the film provides that much needed sense of goodness.

name: The Lone Ranger
desc: An 'origin tale', the visuals show great attention to detail and Depp's Tonto is, without a doubt, the best thing about this movie.

name: Hummingbird
desc: Statham's stony visage tries to emote, often successfully. If this film marks a new direction for Statham's career, he's on the right track.

name: Monsters University 3D
desc: It's not a bad film. Far from that. It is actually quite enjoyable when watched for its own merits and with the entire family. It's endearing in parts.

name: World War Z
desc: If you are a fan of the genre and extreme destruction and survival get your adrenaline flowing, this one’s highly engaging. Be prepared to play hide-and-seek with the terrifying undead creatures.

name: Man of Steel
desc: A hugely impressive and entertaining story of arguably the most powerful character in the superhero pantheon, it’s clear that the Man of Steel is here to stay.

name: After Earth
desc: The film suffers from a lack of ambition. After Earth aims for interstellar overdrive but barely manages to take off.

name: Cinderella 3D
desc: While creative adaptations to fairytales are all very well, this one is just too much of an aggregation of parts that does not make up a wholesome whole.

name: The Hangover Part III
desc: While the film is undoubtedly better than the previous instalment, it's not an out-and-out comedy as one would expect it to be.

name: Epic
desc: It's sometimes slapstick, sometimes emotional, and funny at times. All in all though, the ambitiously-titled Epic is in fact anything but epic.

name: Star Trek Into Darkness
desc: The film will grab you from the opening shot and not let go. Despite a running time of over two hours, you won't feel as though you've been watching for that long because there's not a wasted second.

name: Mud
desc: A coming-of-age story with more than a few moments of menace, the film's languid pace matches the humid atmosphere of the Mississippi delta setting. The visuals are great, with a tinge of surrealism.

name: Iron Man 3
desc: Iron Man 3 is every bit the superhero blockbuster you'd expect it to be. Just do not leave the theatre once the closing credits start rolling!

name: The Host
desc: After romancing vampires and werewolves in the ‘Twilight Saga’, Stephenie Meyer brings ‘aliens’ to the forefront. However, everything else stays constant…love triangle, white makeup, coloured contact lenses, fast cars and most importantly, humans who fall for non-human species!

name: Oblivion
desc: Oblivion is primarily a great visual experience. The mystifying sombreness of a post-apocalyptic earth has been captured brilliantly.

name: The Place Beyond the Pines
desc: Three films cohesively segued into one, the narrative's complexity never once becomes overwrought. However, you will not like this film if you don't like dramatic movies about inter-connected lives.

name: Django Unchained
desc: The trouble begins with the abundance of characters that make their poorly fleshed out appearances and exits with no reason or rhyme attributed to their existence.

name: Texas Chainsaw 3D
desc: For those who seek cheap thrills, the typical slasher ingredients are in place. But avoid, if you can't stand graphic violence.

name: The Master
desc: This film is almost like a vehicle for Phoenix and Hoffman’s acting skills because both their performances are very engaging.

name: The Incredible Burt Wonderstone
desc: For a comedy, it's a little underwhelming. The magic tricks are more shock, less awe. Not as incredible or magical as one would expect. Could do a lot better.

name: Oz the Great and Powerful
desc: The film strongly resembles Tim Burton's Alice In Wonderland. If you fancied that one, you'd definitely love Raimi's feel-good pre-boot of the classic.

name: Jack the Giant Slayer
desc: The film is painfully predictable and the romance awfully sweet. An elongated tug-of-war scene between the humans and giants does not qualify for an epic battle scene and that's the biggest drawback.

name: Silver Linings Playbook
desc: There are tiny quibbles - it could've had a tangent less - but at the end, you're left with pure silver lining and no cloud.

name: A Good Day To Die Hard
desc: The film is a carnival of mindless action, which may appeal to the action junkies, provided you don't expect 'practicality'. The action scenes are not convincing enough to keep you engaged.

name: Lincoln
desc: Its first half's slow, the second quicker but deep-set in American minutiae. Still, as one of its senators finally roars, "God damn it - I'm voting yes."

name: Parker
desc: It is tiring to sit through the entirety of this film (two hours too long), annoying to have to put up with an uneven pace and a seriously imbalanced quality of cast.

name: Midnight's Children
desc: Straight away, Midnight's Children is a love-letter to India. The film takes a difficult novel and mostly does well, producing celluloid that wraps around you like a jamevar shawl.

name: Hansel and Gretel: Witch Hunters
desc: Bond girl Gemma Arterton and 'Hawkeye' Jeremy Renner play siblings who hunt down and kill witches in this classic fairy-tale with a twist.

name: Les Miserables
desc: To truly enjoy this film, be patient (the length IS an issue), persevere (in spite of the sing-song dialogue) and prevail (the film's actually not as tedious as you'd expect a it to be).

name: Broken City
desc: Broken City had the potential to be this dark crime thriller as it involves dangerous secret investigation and murder. The inclusion of politics makes it pale and predictable.

name: Gangster Squad
desc: If you like to witness the battle of good versus evil, mafia and mayhem, Gangster Squad has enough fire, guns and bullets to keep you engaged!

name: Universal Soldier: Day of Reckoning
desc: With at least some scenes that make you cringe over sheer brutality, this film is meant only for those Van Damme fans. One wishes this film had more bite and less bark and growl.

name: CZ12
desc: Recommended solely for those who enjoy Chan's unique brand of humour-laden action with light doses of preachiness and drama, this one could be better, so much better.

name: The Impossible
desc: The movie gets a bit heavy-handed at times but it can be reasoned that this is Bayona's attempt at telling the story as realistically and graphically as possible.

name: Jack Reacher
desc: The film is more of a cerebral drama than a fast-paced, modern action flick. The suspense is satisfying and so is Cruise's 'true to character' performance.

name: Rise Of The Guardians
desc: The film has a message but is not preachy, showing how we should never stop believing in good, no matter what the odds. The film will appeal to all age groups.

name: The Collection
desc: If you get queasy at the sight of spilled guts and grey matter, shredded skin and severed body parts, you're probably better off this film. But if you are a fan of the genre, it is worth a watch.

name: Red Dawn
desc: The film is unintentionally funny and this very aspect entertains you the most unfortunately! The film is not slow or dull but it is way too immature for you to like it.

name: The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey
desc: The only issue could be the running time - almost three hours long. But for a subject of this scale, it's completely justified. Good for the entire family.

name: Life of Pi
desc: Ang Lee interweaves adventure and spirituality brilliantly. And if you still don't know what meditation feels like, Watch Life of Pi, it is therapeutic and profound.

name: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn - Part 2
Wreck-It Ralph
desc: The film is remarkable in that it takes you on a multi-generational gaming trip, sparking off an aching nostalgia for all things retro while keeping true to its real story.

name: Top Cat
desc: As a film for children, this one is avoidable as it would only be a bore due to its length and lack of genuinely good humour.

name: Chasing Mavericks
desc: Chasing Mavericks is a good watch, purely for the subject and not the treatment. It’s an inspiring tale with huge potential of making a mark as a biopic.

name: Stolen
desc: Stolen is one of those films where, ten minutes in, you can pretty accurately predict how things will pan out. There aren’t many surprises here.

name: Trouble With The Curve
desc: No significant events happen in the film, it’s about how you deal with situations when life happens to you. It’s a simple story, brilliantly told.

name: Cloud Atlas
desc: It’s intelligently made: while the first half of the movie’s stories progress forward, the second half goes somewhat backwards in history. There is some deadweight here.

name: Premium Rush
desc: Premium Rush is fairly coherent, the bike stunts are cool and the film is filled with fast-paced chases that will often have you at the edge of your seat.

name: Argo
desc: You will sense a fine balance and an acute attention to detailing. Watch out for certain powerful crowd scenes and set pieces that grab you with their sheer intensity and absolute terror.

name: Taken 2
desc: This is one of those revenge flicks where you know how it could end but you'll strap on your seatbelt and go along for the ride anyway.

name: Looper
desc:
Time travel is invented in the future but is soon made illegal. Misusing this system however, are mob bosses, who send their victims 
into the past to be shot by ‘loopers’, so that their very existence is wiped out.

name: Killing Them Softly
desc: KTS captures America's enormity, emptiness and excitement - often killing the listener with silence. And some dynamite lines.

name: Resident Evil: Retribution
desc: The fifth installment has its share of action -- bullets, bombs and the zombies in thousands -- that makes you sit up as the blood and gore hits your face.

name: Dredd 3D
desc: As long as the bullets keep whizzing -- there are a couple of slow, dead and non-action moments-- Dredd 3D has things going its way.

name: Fire in Babylon
desc: It's a vibrant, throbbing piece of world history told through the tale of test cricket played by one nation - the West Indies. Catch it.

name: Sammy 2
desc: If you can keep all that man versus animal fight aside and enjoy the great plan the sea creatures have in order to execute the greater escape, you might as well give Sammy 2 a shot.

name: Moonrise Kingdom
desc: Bringing life to all this drama -- not for a single moment does all that teen-turned-adult philosophies and ideologies look comic -- are the performance by the leads, Jared Gilman and Kara Hayward.

name: Special Forces
desc: What really makes Special Forces a little different is the very opening line of the movie that gives us ample food for thought -- The only way to change the world is to change the story.

name: Tarbosaurus 3D
desc: What works for Tarbosaurus 3D IS dinosaurs, dinosaurs and more dinosaurs. After all, the film talks about the tarbosaurus that lived some 80 million years ago.

name: Gone
desc: What makes Gone watchable is the climax when all scores are settled with the bad guy. Precisely the moment when you feel some tension building up. However, all seems lost to the otherwise weak plot.

name: To Rome With Love
desc: Unfortunately, it is the script -- too many characters, too many sub plots, too many unexplained fundas/stories -- that leaves you rather disappointed.

name: Hit and Run
desc: Just settle for some situational comedy amidst the backdrop of Pure Imagination from Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory and Let My Love Open the Door, and you’d say this one is watchable.

name: Bel Ami
desc: Just make sure you've read the classic novel by Guy de Maupassant so that the somewhat missing links in the script help you connect everything.

name: Shark Night 3D
desc: Watch Shark Night 3D and you are left guessing what genre this one actually fits into. It is neither a drama nor a horror nor a comedy.

name: Finding Nemo 3D
desc: Watch Finding Nemo (in 3D) if you have never seen it before. Watch Finding Nemo once again – this time in 3D -- if you have seen it all before.

name: The Expendables 2
desc: It’s these bunch of cronies, trapped in the orgy of death and destruction, making up for all that misses... and of course hits. Time to settle down for some vintage bang-bang stuff!

name: The Cold Light of Day
desc: Don’t go with too many expectations... and you shall not complain between all that twists and turns in this conspiracy action thriller.

name: Total Recall
desc: The plot is almost same as the 1990 film of the same name, but rest assured, Total Recall 2012 is understandably more hi-tech, racy and edge-of-the-seat kind of sci-fi thriller.

name: Step Up Revolution
desc: If dance is what you're looking for, you are not going to be disappointed. But if it's the plot, we should notify that it isn't that great.

name: Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter
desc: It’s writer Seth Grahame-Smith kicking all that Vampire butt and director Timur Bekmambetov who makes sure to add his bit to this entertaining and engrossing slice of historical revisionism.

name: The Intouchables
desc: A feel-good dramedy... against the sparkling Paris by night. A feel-good real life story of two buddies who still continue to live happily ever after even today.

name: Dylan Dog: Dead of Night
desc: It is watchable, for the movie is based on Tiziano Sclavi's Italian comic book series by the same name. So thrill, action, speed, chase, mystery and supernatural are there in aplenty.

name: The Amazing Spider-Man
desc: In case you’re expecting a take-two of the famous upside-down Spider-Man-Kirsten Dunst kiss, rest assured: you're not going to be disappointed. Something different in here, but equally smart.

name: Piranha 3DD
desc: Like the prequel, Piranha 3DD makes sure there is blood splattered across the screen while all are reduced to skeletons.

name: Rock Of Ages
desc: Don’t go looking for a great plot and something you have never seen before. Making up for that is the setting of LA of 80s, generously peppered with Rock’s greatest anthems.

name: Prometheus
desc: All you sci-fi fans, Prometheus is an intellectual scientific adventure of epic grandeur. In fact, make sure you indulge in a more-than-one-time-viewing of the movie to get the idea bang on.

name: Madagascar 3: Europe’s Most Wanted
desc: The film has eye-popping visuals, vibrant animation, rib-tickling teasers, nuclear reactors, never ending chases, and a joyous abandon that makes for perfect tween fare.

name: Horrible Bosses
desc: Some oh-I-can-relate-to-that-stereotypical character, good performances, crazy situations and you are sure to laugh your way to theatres.

name: Snow White And The Huntsman
desc: It’s the length of the movie that seems a way too long. But then all is justified when first time director, Rupert Sanders, gets back to the tried and tested fairly tale formula right in time.

name: The Grey
desc: The real winner – surprisingly – here is the pack of wolves. Their wails, their howls, their barks, their whimper, their sparkling eyes and their ferocious attacks are enough to give you the chills.

name: Men in Black III 3D
desc: The MIB gave us good comedy, great special effects, inspiring performances, and ample action. Welcome to Circa 2012 and nothing much seems to have changed.

name: The Raven
desc: There are tense moments, chases, one puzzle leading to the other. There’s also a Victorian setting, a serial-killer, his tricks... and of course, Edgar Allen Poe’s macabre tales.

name: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark
desc: In case you are wondering where all that fear factor is, and what really works in this dark, horror movie, it's the very title: Don’t be afraid of the dark. Literally!

name: Dr. Seuss’ The Lorax
desc: What really takes you by surprise (considering the original was written sometime in 1971) is the 'then' and 'now' setting.

name: Love, Lies and Seeta
desc: For those mad about Manhattan, the only thing that stands out here is a lively shot of the Grand Central station. For the rest, skip Love, Lies...and go for a siesta instead.

name: The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel
desc: Now just when you think this one is going to be yet another when-Hollywood-meets-India story, director John Madden proves you wrong. It’s more about hope.

name: What To Expect When You're Expecting
desc: The challenge for the filmmaker was to add a storyline to an otherwise plain to-do-or-not-to-do listings for those on the threshold of mommy-hood as well as daddy-hood. It does meet that challenge.

name: Dark Shadows
desc: After having swept you off your feet in seven different movies, the Burton-Depp duo return to tell us why this celluloid rendition of Dan Curtis’ soap opera was the talk of the town in the 1960s.

name: The Raid: Redemption
desc: In this day and age when the whizzing of bullets and explosion of bombs bring an end to the vicious war lords on screen, here is your chance to indulge is some raw action.

name: Hugo
desc: Hugo lives up to the pages it owes its creation to – Brian Selznick’s The Invention of Hugo Cabret. Martin Scorsese ensures even the feel of the movie is in sync with the literary version.

name: Safe
desc: The action, is crispy and smart. As for the storyline, guess it was always meant to tread on safe ground... nothing that you have never seen before.

name: The Avengers
desc: Just settle down with your 3D glasses for some bang-bang stuff where VFX speak louder than guns and the super guys have nothing to fall back on, other than their muscles, reflexes and super powers.

name: 21 Jump Street
desc: What you really do not expect turns out to be the highpoint of 21 Jump Street. Ghosts from the past, in this case one's college life, staring right into the face.

name: Mirror Mirror
desc: Agreed it's new. Agreed it's different. And agreed it's the fairy tale from the evil Queen's perspective. But then it is not Hollywood's Snow White tale really the fairest of them all.

name: Battleship
desc: Battleship has enough battles for all gaming buffs. There is non-stop action, unlimited explosions, adrenaline pumping moments, balls of fire, weird looking creatures and do-or-die moments.

name: Titanic 3D
desc: You won’t mind seeing the Titanic sink all over again - in 3D exactly a hundred years from the moment it actually happened.

name: The Hunger Games
desc: There are swords, bows and arrows, knives, deadly bees, dense forests, computerized beasts, tree climbing, balls of fire, do or die instincts, a (not-so-happening) romantic plot.

name: Extremely Loud & Incredibly Close
desc: A meaner editor could have trimmed director Stephen Daldry's movie by 10 minutes making it a tighter, neater work. The film has some fine performances.

name: The Iron Lady
desc: Streep and Helland have not only ensured that the movie engages the regular viewer; they have also made it must-watch in every acting workshop; hence an afterlife.

name: Carnage
desc: With polished performances by the entire cast -- Foster and Waltz marginally more persuasive than the other two -- Carnage is another Polanski special in its own way.

name: My Week with Marilyn
desc: Filmed partly in the picture postcard British countryside, the movie is another elegy to the legend of Marilyn Monroe. It is also an ode to young love.

name: The Artist
desc: Leisurely paced and filmed in an old-fashioned way that reminds one of the best of Charlie Chaplin, The Artist is a tribute to silent cinema, indeed to an age.

name: Moneyball
desc: The beauty of Moneyball lies in being able to transcend itself to a universal drama of collective redemption. Moneyball is studded with diamonds in more than one way.

name: Ghost Rider: Spirit of Vengeance 3D
desc: The Ghost Rider is back. There’s more action, more speed runs, more bombing, more hi-tech equipment, more biking craze, more pacts with the devil, more good versus evil wars, more VFX 3D style.

name: Safe House
desc: It is Denzel Washington who once again is seen doing what he does best. His facial expressions and the goatee are enough to give that suave, convincing look of a man on the run.

name: A Good Old Fashioned Orgy
desc: Watch the buddies take notes from videos, magazines and visit sex clubs to get a hands-on experience. Just the time when you get your dose of laughter.

name: The Woman in Black
desc: The setting of the film is dark, convincing, timeless. The haunted house in the middle of nowhere (literally) is enough to send chills down your spine. There are plenty of horror moments in the film.

name: War Horse
desc: It’s all about blood and gore in there. One cannot miss out on the destructing, thought provoking visuals of war. Typically Spielberg.

name: Journey 2: The Mysterious Island
desc: Journey 2: The Mysterious Island is nothing less than a joyride. The dazzling visual 3D effect keeps you entertained.

name: Chronicle
desc: The camera work grows with every scene - from the initial bedroom confessions of teens to cars smashing, window panes being ripped apart, buildings turning into dust.

name: Contraband
desc: Mark Wahlberg seems to have mastered the art of the no-nonsense-guns-and barrels guy. Perhaps, that is why, his Chris seems like a cakewalk.

name: Haywire
desc: There aren't many twists and turns, but there are some of Hollywood's bigwigs to watch out for: Michael Fassbender, Ewan McGregor, Channing Tatum.

name: Umizaru 3: The Last Message
desc: So what’s the (last) message? It's pretty loud and clear just like the prequels - You've got to be clear on what is dearer : That block of natural resources worth crores or human life. Take your pick.

name: Good Night Good Morning
desc: You don't really need a big star cast to send the right message across. Likewise, you don't even need a big budget to the get the techniques of filmmaking bang on.

name: Underworld Awakening: Vengeance Returns
desc: The war between the vampires and the werewolves gives you a couple of jolts. The leather-clad, bloodsucking Kate who, with action unlimited, has ample in store for that extra dose of adrenaline.

name: J. Edgar
desc: If you really wanna know how power could actually drive you up the wall and get you to do things you would not otherwise, watch it.

name: Coriolanus
desc: Its relevance is as contemporary as it can get -- territorial wars, riots, people’s movement, revolts, protests, scheming, stabbing. But that’s not the only thing Coriolanus lays claim to.

name: The Darkest Hour
desc: For the 3D, there's ample scope - the Moscow setup, deserted roads, abandoned cars, man turning into ash, collapsing buildings and the very aliens as pieces of fireballs - wasted in some parts.

name: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows
desc: The film is a relentless action experience which gives enough to adrenaline hunters to get an overdose. The visual appeal will not leave you disappointed nor will the plot.

name: Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy
desc: It's a gripping, high profile hunt of a double agent working for the Soviets -- now very much a part of MI6. Making up for loopholes is a varied range of performances to choose from.

name: One Day
desc: Watch it for its adaptation of David Nicholl’s bestseller -- the pages of the book do seem to come to life, though in bits and pieces.

name: Mission: Impossible - Ghost Protocol
desc: The new film is a relentless roller-coaster ride that doesn’t give you a moment to sit back and keeps the adrenalin pumping to dizzy heights as Tom Cruise gets on his mission of saving the world.

name: Machine Gun Preacher
desc: What really makes up for all in this good-man-versus-evil battle is a short cameo of the real Sam Childers firing shotgun.

name: Puss in Boots
desc: The animation is excellent, the voice-overs great and the action fast-paced. Yes, Puss in Boots is a fun watch for the entire family.

name: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 1
desc: If you view Breaking Dawn Part 1 basically as a prequel to the hell and high drama that is about to break through in part two, then rest assured, you shall have no problem with the pace of the film.

name: The Help
desc: Watch this journey of three extraordinary women who not only build an unlikely friendship, but question the 1960 Mississippi society, fraught with exploitative undertones.

name: Happy Feet Two
desc: The excellent music and dancing leaves you in a tap dance mode yourself. Also, the 3D’s definitely smarter, brighter and trendier.

name: Gangs of New York-2002
desc: This one's a classic that traces the birth of America, not in civilised boardrooms where the principles of democracy are debated and pondered upon; but through bloody street brawls and hate crimes.

name: The Aviator
desc: The film belongs to Leonardo alone who grows from 18 to adulthood without losing the core of his character: a dreamer-doer who didn't quite have it right.

name: GoodFellas
desc: Good Fellas is director Martin Scorsese's greatest ode to gangster Henry Hill with Ray Liotta pitching in a towering act as the guy who wanted to be a gangster rather than the President of America.

name: Raging Bull
desc: Robert De Niro, in the lead role, is all guts and fury especially in the hard-hitting boxing sequence. But his emotional sequences with brother Joe Pesci are classic cuts.

name: Taxi Driver
desc: It’s a startling, disturbing picture of social disarray, with De Niro redefining the angst of a socially dysfunctional citizen who has been transformed into a rage machine.

name: The Adventures of Tintin: Secret of the Unicorn
desc: It could have ended up as a heady cocktail of the Indiana Jones and the Pirates of the Caribbean series, but The Adventures of Tintin is so much more than recycled headiness.

name: Immortals
desc: The problem with Immortals is its garbled screenplay, its lacklustre, almost lifeless action cuts, making the film end up as a pale shadow of the mesmerising '300'.

name: The Rum Diary
desc: The film is rich in atmospherics and captures the 1950's Puerto Rico beautifully. The screenplay is however a bit muddled and confusing here and there. But Depp is first rate.

name: In Time
desc: Watch for it Cillian Murphy as the selfish, sophisticated time keeper in a not-so-distant world where time is money and speedy car chases and crashes, gun shots and other adrenaline pumping stuff.

name: The Whistleblower
desc: Watch it for Rachel as a body of patience, calm, determination and composure even during moments of helplessness while she is stripped off her last power.

name: Paranormal Activity 3
desc: All is lost to the tedious intervals between each scary moment and too much of camera running into non-happening space and time. Works for a one-time watch.

name: Real Steel
desc: This one's a classic on how to blend techno-splendour with high emotions, without going all mushy and sentimental. Sporty. Soft. Super. Scram for it.

name: Doraemon In Nobita and The Steel Troops: New Age
30 Minutes Or Less
desc: Crazy bank heists, gangster encounters and car chases make for some funny situations which keep the minutes flying. The film delivers the goods.

name: Drive
desc: Worth getting behind the wheel this weekend, both for the drives and for the driver. Don't miss this action-bender which got a standing ovation at Cannes.

name: Abduction
desc: Truly, a befitting breakaway attempt, Abduction proves that Lautner has more to him than being a sidekick to Robert Pattinson's vampire hero in the Twilight films.

name: Johnny English Reborn
desc: All in all, Johnny English is a fun film to watch at the weekend with Rowan Atkinson showing off his characteristic flair for comedy once again.

name: Warrior
desc: This one’s high on testosterone -- brutal martial arts with solid punches. And it’s equally high on EQ too -- emotionally packaged with rewards.

name: Friends With Benefits
desc: It's the chemistry between Timberlake and Kunis which is smooth, perfect, crackling. You actually end up giving them the benefit of doubt despite the romcom's cliches!

name: Conan the Barbarian
desc: The 2011 version does make you nostalgic for the original 1982 Conan where Arnold Schwarzenneger immortalised the Barbarian with his wooden -- yet winsome -- pure beefcake act.

name: The Devil's Double
desc: It's an ostentatiously mounted, although a somewhat meandering film, which creates high drama out of cut and dried political facts. Don't miss it.

name: Spy Kids: All The Time in The World
Captain America: The First Avenger
desc: America sure knows how to script the best super hero story. So what if it can't hold on to its super power status any longer. Have fun with America's fictional folk lore.

name: Final Destination 5
desc: The death scenes have shock value and sometimes end up as funny too: black humour, you see. Often, you have to shut your eyes at the sheer bloodiness of it all. Go, test your appetite for gore.

name: Rise of the Planet of the Apes
desc: It's warm, it's sensitive, it's dramatic, it's larger-than-life... Yes, Rise of the Planet of the Apes is spectacular cinema with loads of lessons for money and power obsessed mankind.

name: The Tree of Life
desc: The film boasts of fine performances, specially by Brad Pitt and the young McCracken and spills over with so much mood and atmospherics, it’s bound to strike a chord.

name: The Smurfs 3D
desc: The adventures of the Smurfs in the malls, streets and parks (Central Park) of New York keep you guzzling on your popcorn, with not a care in the world.

name: Harry Potter And The Deathly Hallows Part 2
Green Lantern
desc: This one's straight out of DC comics. The battles are top notch. The special effects are worth most of the money. Enjoyable and fun, in places.

name: West is West
desc: The performances are all impressive, specially by Om Puri and Ila Arun. The humour is delightful. But what finally takes your breath away is the soulful music of the film.

name: Something Borrowed
desc: If you've seen and savoured Julia Robert's wicked antics in My Best Friend's Wedding, there would be little reason why you would enjoy this pale copy of livelier treatise on love versus friendship.

name: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides
Priest 3D
desc: Bettany is in great form as the maverick man of God. But more than the performances, it is the well-choreographed action sequences that keep you glued to your seats.

name: Fast & Furious: Fast Five
desc: There are enough brazen races here to send your testosterone into a tizzy and keep you glued to your seats, seat belts on.

name: Water For Elephants
desc: The film is as much an ode to the extravaganza that circuses used to be, as it is an enigmatic, old-fashioned Hollywood romance. Sit back and savour Hollywood in retro mood.

name: Source Code
desc: The beauty of Source Code lies in its science-meets-superhero tenor and in the fact that the film hurtles across like a relentless thriller, leaving you no room to sit back or even blink.

name: Unknown
desc: Liam Neeson is Dr Martin Harris, a high-profile scientist who is on his way to address a path breaking biotechnology conference in Berlin.

name: The Lincoln Lawyer
desc: Go for McConaughey's high-powered performance as the good-bad lawyer, the chemistry he shares with a sparkling Marisa Tomei and the unpredictable turns this compelling story takes.

name: The Hole 3-D
desc: On the goosebump scale, the film has a few moments that might make you grin sheepishly (yup! you almost got scared). Fun watch.

name: From Prada To Nada
desc: Don't go looking for Emma Thompson, Kate Winslet, Hugh Grant, Alan Rickman and the sensibility of Ang Lee and you might just find this a pleasant watch.

name: Red Riding Hood
desc: Watch it for the excellent production design, the breath-taking cinematography (Mandy Walker) and for Amanda Seyfried's rendition of go-go girls who gotta break some rules.

name: The King's Speech
desc: The King's Speech may be a historical film, but for cine-buffs hungry for refined cinema, this one may go down as celluloid history: an uplifting document on the human spirit.

name: The Way Back
desc: Weir's films may not be mainstream, but they have a flavour that suitably engages the serious film buff. The Way Back is a gripping watch.

name: Drive Angry
desc: It is this unpredictable journey into the world of the undead that makes this drive a crazy ride. Enjoy, full throttle.

name: True Grit
desc: It is the gritty narrative and the purist style that pulls you towards this old-fashioned tale of old-fashioned valour. Don't miss it.

name: The Fighter
desc: A story of two half-brothers who try to create history in the boxing ring, the film is based on a real life story of Micky Ward.

name: I Am Number Four
desc: We don't get to really know what bothers the Mogadarians, but be ready to see more of them as this comic book caper shows enough promise to generate sequels. A fun watch.

name: The Nutcracker
desc: This one's a picturesque parable that has acquired cult status in its ballet form. This time, it re-appears as a straight feature that holds appeal, both for kids and adults. Great fun.

name: Rabbit Hole
desc: Watch out for Nicole's Oscar nominated performances as the dysfunctional woman, desperately trying to regain her equilibrium. It's delicate and dignified.

name: The Mechanic
desc: This one's a sure-watch for Statham fans. Of course don't commit the folly of watching the 1972 version before this because Jason Statham can never stand up to Charles Bronson.

name: Biutiful
desc: Biutiful is a gritty ode to the human spirit which never does give up, even if all the odds are piled up against it.

name: Alpha & Omega
desc: This one's quite indeterminate. Neither cute enough for kids, nor smart enough for adults, the wolfish affair has nothing much to offer to anyone.

name: Burlesque
desc: It may have a predictable plot and a done-to-death drama, but Burlesque keeps you attentive with its colours, cadence and canvas.

name: Little Fockers
desc: The Focker franchise which was such a rib-tickler in its earlier versions does seem to have lost some of its fun in the third sequel.

name: The Season Of The Witch
desc: There is too much mumbo-jumbo and old-fashioned tantra-mantra in The Season of The Witch to engage the modern mindset.

name: Tangled
desc: The state-of-the-art 3-D transforms the fairy tale into an eye-popping story. Go get your fill, with friends and family.

name: Another Year
desc: Watch the film for its compelling performances, specially by Leslie Manville, who is absolutely brilliant as the sad yet strong and self-respecting Mary.

name: The Green Hornet
desc: Witty dialogues, bumbling heroes, zany bad guys, high-voltage action, The Green Hornet is a fun make-over of the super hero movie. Don't miss it.

name: Life As We know It
desc: Sentimental, sweet and spilling over with slapstick gags, Life As We Know It is Hollywood romance, as we know it. Fun while it lasts.

name: Gulliver's Travels
desc: Watch out for Jack Black's zany rendition of the classic hero who is first held captive by pint-sized people and then punched around by a giant-sized doll.

name: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger
desc: The film isn't writer-director Woody Allen's best. But if you've seen 39 of his earlier films, you must see the 40th too!

name: The Tourist
desc: Elise (Angelina Jolie), a mysterious woman who is under surveillance by Scotland Yard, the Interpol and a bunch of bad guys, meets and falls in love with an American tourist, Frank (Johnny Depp).

name: Tron: Legacy
desc: You do sit and gawk at the natty 3-D elegance and the combat-game format which has anyhow captured the 21st century imagination, kids and adults, alike.

name: The Warrior's Way
desc: The film moves languorously, sometimes too slowly, and manages to draw you with its eclectic appeal. Go for the different look and the blending of genres.

name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader
desc: The third part in the fantasy series holds merit on its own and manages to hold you in your seat with its mix of make-believe, special effects and fairy tale folklore.

name: Secretariat
desc: The real drama picks up only in the final few moments of the movie when Secretariat, steals the show with with his racing moments. Exciting yet predictable.

name: Unstoppable
desc: The film does move on predictable lines, nevertheless, the well-crafted sound and action sequences make the film worth a visit.

name: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1
From Paris With Love
desc: James Reece , an aide to the US ambassador in Paris, has just got engaged to a beautiful French girl, Caroline and would like to spend the rest of the week serenading her.

name: The Other Guys
desc: Light and breezy, The Other Guys is your cop house comedy which runs through a familiar track where fifteen minutes of fame do come, but only when our common man types have been tried and tested.

name: Letters to Juliet
desc: Set against the breathtaking scenery of the Tuscan backdrop, Letters to Juliet is a love story that makes you want to believe in the legend of Romeo and Juliet.

name: Eat Pray Love
desc: The film manages to carry you through its cross-country journey, peppered with scenic locales and attention-grabbing characters, the credit for which goes to Julia Roberts.

name: Beauty And the Beast
desc: There's the sublime beauty of a forgotten world and the promise of happily-ever-after to draw you to one of your favourite fairy tales, once again. Give it an encore.

name: A Distant Mirage
desc: Sadly, there isn't enough -- neither story, nor performances -- to sustain a decent run for A Distant Mirage. Too much has already been said on the issue.

name: Crank: High Voltage
desc: The filmmakers don't seem to be taking themselves seriously. Neither should we. So all you diehard action buffs can take a chance with Crank 2. It is high voltage action, albeit with a jaded edge.

name: Shanghai
desc: The drama might not engage you with its heavy political overtones, its outdated tenor and its overriding seriousness. But the star cast definitely will.

name: Resident Evil: Afterlife
desc: All the alpha and brawn show doesn't stop your attention wavering mid-film when testosterone is side-tracked for testy, long drawn conversation.

name: Avatar:Special Edition
desc: You can hardly spot the difference between the old and the new Avatar, unless you've studied it minutely and seen it several times in its first edition.

name: Cats and Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore
Dinner for Schmucks
desc: Fun while it lasts, Dinner For Schmucks is a black comedy that is paced out and restrained. No loud laughs here. Just gentle chuckles.

name: The Expendables
desc: Don't go looking for a script. Just settle down for some vintage bang-bang stuff where guns were supposed to speak louder than special effects and guys had nothing to fall back on.

name: Grown Ups
desc: Savour the Sandler brand of humour with Grown Ups, a film that once again celebrates the spirit of childhood, like most of his comedies.

name: Despicable Me
desc: Despicable Gru (Steve Carell) has just one ambition. He wants to be the perfect anti-hero and showcase some super villainy. And how does he propose to do so? By stealing the moon. But before he can do that, he must steal into the house of the evil nerd, Vector (Jason Segal) and foil his attempts at a million dollar heist. For this, he needs to adopt three cute orphans from Miss Hattie's Home for Girls. The beginning of the transformation of Superbad Gru to Superdad Gru!

name: Salt
desc: It's Angelina Jolie, all the way. She's extremely watchable as the female agent who commendably stands up to the Bond and Bourne Inc.

name: The Sorcerer's Apprentice
desc: This one's a simple summer flick that keeps the popcorn crisp. However, the story isn't original and does fill you with a sense of deja vu.

name: Knight and Day
desc: The action is completely over the top. And the film is such a chaloo cheeseburst, you just can't miss it. Go, sink your teeth in it.

name: Spread
desc: Watch it for Ashton Kutcher and his pretty boy charms. And also for his existential dilemma: to be a gigolo or a grocery boy.

name: Toy Story 3
desc: There is colour, verve, drama, action, comedy, romance and 3D too. Add to this, a few wonderful take-home morals for our young and old viewers, and what more can you want.

name: The A-Team
desc: The A-Team is strictly for action buffs who love to OD on high-decibel AXN cuts. The action is superbly crafted, leaving no room for anything else.

name: The Karate Kid
desc: The film has a lot to offer to young adults, but fails to rise to cult status. And that's only because the martial arts display is somewhat marginalised by the drama and relationship building.

name: Robin Hood
desc: Go watch this version, because the sequel is bound to follow. And then, we are sure, all hell will break lose....Savour the lull before the storm.

name: Sex and the City 2
desc: The sequel may not be as spunky as the first film, yet, Sex and the City 2 has enough to keep the cosmo club grinning.

name: Nightmare on ELM Street
desc: The new version may not be a revisionist tale and has nothing new to offer but it does have some old fashioned scares that still work.

name: Shutter Island
desc: This one's a gritty drama, with Scorsese creating some marvellous set pieces where the past intervenes with the present and Leonardo creates a compelling picture of brooding disarray.

name: Brick Lane
desc: Watch the film for the grandeur that both Satish Kaushik and Tannishtha Chatterjee invest in their role of the low key couple who try to cope with a changing world order.

name: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time
desc: The high point of the film is its stellar ensemble cast headed by Ben Kingsley who lends gravitas to the entire proceedings as Nizam, the King's brother.

name: Daybreakers
desc: This one's for those who still haven't had their fill of vampire lore which happens to be the current craze in Hollywood and those who like their vampires mostly mean and monster-like.

name: Shrek Forever After
desc: Go watch your favourite ogre live out the ugly-is-beautiful revisionist tale, once again. And make you feel good about it.

name: Remember Me
desc: Set against 9/11, Remember Me is an immensely watchable romance, even as it paints a touching picture of loss and redemption against a violence-scarred backdrop. Raise a toast for RPatz.

name: The Back-Up Plan
desc: It may be nothing to rave about, yet, The Back-Up Plan is good while it lasts, with Jennifer Lopez managing to hold your attention with her attempt at motherhood.

name: The Last Song
desc: The highpoint of the film are the special moments created by Greg Kinnear and Miley Cyrus as they develop a warm and tender father-daughter relationship. Let them tug at your heart.

name: Iron Man 2
desc: The sequel is one hellish and hungama-filled ride into the world of high-octane drama. It may lack the finesse of the first film, but there's enough to keep the adrenalin pumping.

name: Hot Tub Time Machine
desc: The retro scenes do have a comic feel to it, nevertheless, Hot Tub Time Machine lacks the panache of time travel films like Back To The Future. The laughs too come in fits and starts.

name: Astro boy
desc: Astro Boy, with its colourful animation and its dramatic voice-overs is perfect weekend fare for kids who need a break from the violent games on play station.

name: The Bounty Hunter
desc: Funny in places, feisty here and there, The Bounty Hunter, is one more middle-of-the-road outing from Jennifer Aniston.

name: Cop Out
desc: It's crude. It's rude. And it's downright funny, but only in a down and out way. Enjoy the nonsensical, one evening.

name: Green Zone
desc: Don't go looking for the Bourne effect and you'll enjoy the relevance of this film which dares to question and debate.

name: Date Night
desc: The Fosters, a boring couple from New Jersey, go on a routine date to a high end, overbooked restaurant in Manhattan. When they don't get place, they steal someone else's reservation and end up being chased by trigger-happy gangsters and corrupt cops who want them to deliver a stolen flash drive. Can the Fosters, now mistaken as the Triplehorns, deliver and get back to their staid, suburban domesticity?

name: The Hurt Locker
desc: Don't miss this topical teaser of a film that dares to go inside the mind of the young soldier who is herded into the battle field, without actually knowing why.

name: Vicky Cristina Barcelona
desc: The highpoint of the film is the unstable equilibrium the three women try to establish in their interactions with the Don Juan. Penelope Cruz is simply riveting.

name: Gamer
desc: Meant strictly for action-buffs, Gamer is a timely warning for the gaming industry. Too much virtual violence might just turn the real world turtle.

name: The Book of Eli
desc: The film is essentially an extremely well-shot action drama embellished with some fine performances by Denzel Washington and Gary Oldman.

name: New in Town
desc: An inconsequential love story, New in Town acquires body and form only because of Ms Zellweger. Watch it as time-pass. It could make you smile on an average day.

name: Nine
desc: Nine may not be as engrossing as Rob Marshall's other mind-bending musical, Chicago. Nevertheless, it is an enchanting experience with Daniel Day Lewis.

name: Alice In Wonderland
desc: The evergreen fable comes alive in mesmeric form. Don't miss your tryst with a dapper Johnny Depp, a newage Alice and an over-the-top Tim Burton.

name: Love Happens
desc: This one's serious business. Much of the romance between Jennifer Aniston and Aaron Eckhart proceeds on a sombre note, with both our protagonists trying to cope with their personal tragedies.

name: Percy Jackson And The Olympians: The Lightning Thief
desc: Young Percy Jackson is a demi-god (son of a god and a human). He is falsely accused of stealing the lightning bolt and must retrieve it before earth is torn asunder by the warring gods. Aiding him in his search for the missing bolt are Annabeth, the daughter of goddess Athena and Satyr, a half-human, half-goat creature.

name: Up In The Air
desc: A smart script, great performances, witticisms galore, Up In The Air is a humanist document of today's times. Not to be missed at all.

name: Valentine's Day
desc: The film doesn't quite live up to Garry Marshall's rendition of the Cinderella myth in Pretty Woman, but it fits in with the mood of the moment.

name: Old Dogs
desc: Watch out for moments of fun in this routine comedy. Both John Travolta and Robin Williams crackle, despite their aging and weathering.

name: Coco Avant Chanel
desc: Watch the film for its character sketch, its authenticity and for a towering performance by Audrey Tautou in the eponymous role.

name: Bruno
desc: The film may not be as uproarious as Borat but it does give you some rollicking moments with Sacha Baron Cohen unleashing his manic energy once again. Enjoy, the adult way.

name: New York I love you
desc: The film, written by the late Anthony Minghella, is sheer visual poetry, with its white interiors and its hazy outlines.

name: The Spy Next Door
desc: Nothing original and not quite quintessential Chan -- the action here is muted -- this one's only for diehard Jackie buffs.

name: Case 39
desc: As a film, Case 39 does work at the simple, basic level of a thriller that thrills. Although Ms Zellweger does look somewhat jaded and whispers a bit too much to create her characteristic impact.

name: Did You Hear About the Morgans?
desc: The film does have a tired Hugh Grant and a washed out Sarah Jessica Parker trying to be funny. To be fair, they do manage to make you smile, now and then, while the popcorn lasts.

name: Paranormal Activity
desc: Catch the night show if you actually want to feel the heebie-jeebies. And don't go looking for long-winded explanations. You might end up blaming the chill, not on winter alone.

name: Avatar
desc: James Cameron chooses to play God and creates a whole new world with such exquisite finesse, aesthete and eye for detail, he almost takes your breath away.

name: Tinker Bell and The Lost Treasure
desc: This one's a perfect outing for the kids who will have a ball watching the pesky Trolls, taking the 21 butterfly salute or savouring the Fairy Tale Theatre orchestra made up of frogs and crickets.

name: Ninja Assassin
desc: The fight sequences are the highlight of this film. But it has its emotional core too as it captures the angst of young Raizo who tries to quell the thundering of his heart in a heartless world.

name: A Christmas Carol
desc: Loads of special effects and a story that has stood the test of time: Christmas Carol is Carrey revisited. However, it's not really a children's film and is meant for diehard Dicken's fans.

name: Twilight
desc: The film actually works because it sculpts a romance that blooms through self-denial and renunciation. Grab your munchies and go for it!
What really holds your attention is apocalypse itself. Yes, it's the special effects of the film, more than the human drama, which completely sweep you off your feet.

name: Whiteout
desc: The film fails to exploit the exotic locales of the South Pole and the twists and turns are mostly predictable in this tundra thriller which is based on a graphic novel by Greg Rucka.

name: This Is It
desc: Go where you've never been before. Witness the concert that might have been. Experience the magic of a man who made you jump over the moon.

name: Shorts
desc: Just the lack of hi-tech special effects and the chaotic structure of the story which lurches back through a series of disjointed flashbacks. That's where you might end up blinking! Fun, nevertheless.

name: Taking woodstock
desc: For those who'd like to decipher why the hippie cult was so alluring to the earth-bound, Taking Woodstock is low-key yet lyrical.

name: Surrogates
desc: Watch out for the action sequences and Bruce Willis trying to replay some of Arnold Schwarzenneger's Terminator magic.

name: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs
desc: Occasionally funny and inventive, CWCM is like a great-looking dish that only intermittently gets as tasty as it looks.

name: District 9
desc: Disturbingly powerful visual effects and a dark background score add to the film's appeal. Worth a viewing but make sure you only catch the English version.

The machines turned against humans and annihilated them. But they too were largely destroyed. The challenge of reviving civilization falls on a band of 'small creations' who fight the few surviving brutal machines_x000D_

name: The Final Destination
desc: State-of-art technology must upgrade a good narrative but cannot act as its substitute. Sadly, The Final Destination tries precisely that.

name: The Brothers Bloom
desc: There's loads of twists and turns on this road full of bumpy rides. Of course, with ample fun en route! So just in case you feel being taken for a ride is in right now, go for it.

name: G.I. Joe: Rise of the Cobra
desc: If non-stop action thrills is what you're looking for and we don't really mind a rather not-so-packed storyline, it's time to join the G.I. Joe heroes.

name: Ghosts of Girlfriends Past
desc: Just in case you like a romcom that tugs at your heart strings, there's loads of senti speeches, overwhelming cuteness, romantic-realisation-of-love moments and tender touches.

name: Public Enemies
desc: The film is a cinematic treat with its artistic canvas, its fine detailing and its towering portrayal of a real-life bandit by Johnny Depp.

name: Red Cliff
desc: Don't go looking for Zhang Yimou's period epics; nor expect the anti-gravity athleticism of Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon and you might just be mesmerised by John Woo's grandiose battles.

name: Night at the Museum: Battle of the Smithsonian
Boarding Gate
desc: The clock keeps ticking in this taut thriller that doesn't really boast of anything original, other than Ms Asia and her antics.

name: Harry Potter And The Half-Blood Prince
The Proposal
desc: It may be unabashedly sentimental and predictably romantic, yet The Proposal manages to win you over with its sassy script and showstopper Sandra.

name: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs
The Hangover
desc: A great fun ride, The Hangover introduces a whole new bunch of talent to Hollywood, specially Zach, the nerd. Don't miss it.

name: Bolt
desc: Now this one's a fun film for the entire family, with little lessons on love and friendship you can carry home with you. Lessons you learn from a dog, a cat and a hamster.

name: Bride Wars
desc: Feminists would surely bare their fangs at this one, which sees the girls stooping to silly lows in their game of come-uppance. But the rest might just find it silly and funny. Take your pick.

name: Angels and Demons
desc: Angels and Demons is one of the most engrossing masala films from current Hollywood. We bet you'll forget your popcorns too!

name: Chocolate
desc: Go for the adrenalin-pumping action sequences which are pure art, in terms of their perfect hand-foot-eye coordination. The film reminds you of Tarantino's hand combat tricks in the Kill Bill series.

name: Cabin Fever
desc: Watch it, if you can handle the preponderance of red -- oodles and oodles of blood dripping from the screen, with scenes of stomach-churning muck that's definitely not meant for the faint-hearted.

name: New Police Story 5
desc: Watch out for regular Chan fare, which includes some dizzy action sequences and high-octane chases that never seem to tire the action junkie in you.

name: Pride and Glory
desc: Edward Norton, the good NYPD cop, tries to bust a drug deal and comes up with startling evidence that implicates his family. His elder brother, Noah Emmerich and brother-in-law, Colin Farrell may also be cops, but their record isn't clean.

name: The Year My Parents Went on Vacation
desc: Watch it for its alluring recreation of the life and times of the ordinary Brazilian who attains nirvana with Pele's magical footwork and for its powerful performances.

name: Watchmen
desc: Watchmen isn't as hard-hitting and stomach-churning as 300, nevertheless it creates a canvas of stirring images and enigmatic characters that keep you riveted.

name: Elegy
desc: Watch it for the rich fabric and the intense chemistry between Ben Kingsley and Penelope Cruz who set the screen on fire with their passion and anguish.

name: One Man Army
desc: The film's a visual delight for martial arts buffs and is a waft of fresh breeze in the overcrowded world of chopsucky cinema.

name: Fast and Furious 4
desc: There is the enigmatic characterisation of Vin Diesel as the good-bad Dom, who keeps you guessing about his ethics till the very end. Get your testosterone kick.

name: The Class
desc: The film is a must for all educationalists as it brings to light a whole new system of education where interactivity is the key word.

name: Anywhere But Home
desc: What's missing in this film is both warmth and humour. The gags are too loud and the bonding too clinical to actually make you a believer too, like the protagonists who forget fun in Fiji for family.

name: Underworld lll: Rise of the Lycans
desc: Watch the film for its special effects and its cinematography which lends an eerie, grey chill to the high-voltage action sequences between weird creatures.

name: Confessions of a Shopaholic
desc: Watch the film for a zany comic act by Isla Fisher who almost perfects the role of the ditzy chick who ain't as dumb as you think.

name: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2
desc: This is essentially a more serious version of Sex and the City, where the protagonists are younger, their concerns are more real and their journey towards self-realisation strikes a deeper chord.

name: Gran Torino
desc: Uplifting, topical and absolutely engaging, Gran Torino posits an answer to the current clash-of-cultures theory that seems to have sent the new world in a tizzy.

name: Talk To Me
desc: A biopic based on the life of Petey Greene (Don Cheadle), a convict who became a legendary DJ and TV talk show artist, the film is a compelling story of individual atonement.

name: Street Kings
desc: Intelligently paced, with enough thrills to keep the adrenalin pumping, Street Kings unleashes the Keanu charisma after a long time.

name: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford
desc: It's a long, meandering film which keeps you engrossed with its hard-hitting performances and its intricate eye for detail.

name: Out of Bounds
desc: Does money justify a dehumanised life? 'Out of Bounds' has won requisite applause at sundry international film festivals for addressing this question with style and sensitivity.

name: Turtles Can Fly
desc: The film leaves you devastated with its chilling climax and shakes you out of your stupor, even as it overawes you with its powerful imagery of the wasteland that is war. Don't miss it..

name: Emotional Arithmetic
desc: Watch it for the unresolved equations and questions that must definitely mar the life of any and every one who survives a violent act of history.

name: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button
desc: Based on a story by F Scott Fitzgerald, the film is essentially a fantasy that recreates the flavour of Forrest Gump. Watch the film for it's curious flavour.

name: Valkyrie
desc: While Hitler largely figures as a silhouette in the film, it is Tom Cruise who remains as the tormented military man with a conscience that precluded him from raising his hand to 'Hail Hitler!'

name: Milk
desc: Watch it for an unforgettable performance by Sean Penn who is heroic in his ordinariness, proving that outliers and high-flyers are made, not born.

name: What Just Happened
desc: Recipe enough for loads of drama that keeps the entertainment meter alive and kicking. But not really something you'd expect from Raging Bull, Robert DeNiro.

name: He's just not that into you
desc: This one's sheer candy floss, meant for a Valentine viewing. Don't go looking for heart-tugging romance and you won't end up disappointed.

name: Redline
