desc: Despite a poor plot, there's enough in this movie to keep the testosterone-filled spirits upbeat, specially for speed addicts and auto freaks with the rollicking car parade.

name: Seven Pounds
desc: Seven Pounds is a sincerely told, mushy tale about spreading good cheer and making the world a better place, with Smith essaying the role of the tormented do-gooder with impeccable zeal.

name: How To Lose Friends and Alienate People
desc: The film is a witty adaptation of journalist Toby Young's autobiographical account of the years he spent at Vanity Fair and his brush with Page 3 journalism.

name: Outlander
desc: Nothing outlandish about this one, specially if you've seen the more evolved versions of alien monsters, like Predator and Species.

name: Honeydripper
desc: Like a rich and fading tapestry, the film successfully manages to create a lost world, a lost time. That we may never forget.

name: Meet Bill
desc: Camp fires, crackers, pyjama parties coupled with some hardballed fisticuffs is all it takes to make befuddled Bill come of age. Only, the fun parts seem to elude the viewer completely in this meandering, plotless venture.

name: Bedtime Stories
desc: He's the archetypal Mr Under-Appreciated by now. For Adam Sandler has never really digressed from his first few roles of the affable underdog that made him a household name, some years ago.

name: Slumdog Millionaire
desc: Slumdog Millionaire is just a piece of riveting cinema, meant to be savoured as a Cinderella-like fairy tale, with the edge of a thriller and the vision of an artist.

name: I'm Not There
desc: For those who are hoping to find a straight biopic about the legendary singer, this one's definitely not the ‘Once there was Robert Allen Zimmerman aka Bob Dylan' kinda thing.

name: Flashbacks of a Fool
desc: Baillie Walsh's this dramatic film begins on a promising note. As the opening credits start rolling, the music played in the background soothes your heart and the visuals of the enchanting friendship shared between two young boys make you nostalgic.

name: Changeling
desc: The film has been directed as a detailed period piece about an age when no one thought of photographic evidence or DNA testing.This one falls short of Eastwood's other highs.

name: The President Is Coming
desc: The film has a raw look and lacks finesse when it comes to production values. But there is a delightful tongue-in-cheek tenor running through it, which makes you overlook the unpolished feel and the loose editing.

name: Australia
desc: Set against the tumult of World War ll, the director shifts his drama to Australia, complete with it's characteristic slangs, lingo, cows, horses, farming, landscape, aborigines, celebrations and folktales.

name: Outsourced
desc: Life's a relentless question mark for products salesman Todd Anderson (Josh Hamilton) when he is sent to India to train his replacement.

name: In Bruges
desc: It's a smart gangster film, with some high powered acting by Colin Farrell as the conscience-stricken, suicidal hitman who has killed a small boy on his first assignment.

name: Razzle Dazzle
desc: What really keeps glittering in this razzle dazzle of reality shows is Darren Ashton’s own chicken curry for the soul.

name: Madagascar 2: Escape to Africa
desc: This film is charming, with eye-popping visuals, vibrant animation, rib-tickling teasers and a joyous abandon that makes for perfect tweeny fare.

name: High School Musical 3: Senior Year
desc: High School Musical 3 follows a similar storyline where a bunch of drama school undergrads must put up a musical before they go their separate ways.

name: In The Name of the King
desc: Set in a strange era -- the kingdom of Ehb -- where kings were poisoned and evil magicians ruled, the film has a dark, sepia tone that doesn't quite match up to the visual splendour.

name: The Page Turner
desc: This film is a taut French thriller that treats the leitmotif of revenge like vintage wine that grows more heady with age.

name: The Hunting Party
desc: It's a gritty, nerve-wracking thriller that sees unusual threesome -- seasoned journos, Gere and Howard and Harvard graduate, greenhorn Eisenberg -- embark on a do-or-die mission. So get your thrills.

name: The Day the Earth Stood Still
desc: The film is essentially a re-make of a 1951 film and traces the journey of an alien, Klaatu (Keanu Reeves) in New York.

name: Still Life
desc: Based on the real life Three Gorges Dam Project on the Yangste River which demolished the entire ancient town of Fenjgie, the camera accompanies the two protagonists - a coal mine worker and a nurse.

name: Burn After Reading
desc: Burn After Reading is an arresting piece of a crime-gone-awry drama with an unconventional act by both George Clooney and Brad Pitt who discover their negative shades with apblomb.

name: Transporter 3
desc: The Transporter is back. This time with a human cargo: the kidnapped Natalya Rudakova who needs to be delivered to her father, a high-ranking Ukaranian government official.

name: Nights in Rodanthe
desc: The script is stale, the narrative tardy. What works is the chemistry of Diane Lane and Richard Gere which has already been displayed in two films, "The Unfaithful" and "The Cotton Club".

name: Max Payne
desc: "Max Payne" lives up to the video gaming formula and offers loads of action, drama, violence, albeit with characters that need no joystick to explode.

name: Eagle Eye
desc: All sound and fury, signifying nothing new! That's the trouble with this new flick on terrorism, where once again America is in danger, with the President and his entire cabinet being the target of attack.

name: 2 Days in Paris
desc: Brimming over with delightful one-liners on clash of cultures, gender differences, sexual mores, the film is a charmer.

name: Quantum of Solace
desc: There's one big problem with this 22nd Bond film. It has been severely depleted of the quantum of Bondness that made this franchise so special, so irresistible, so debonair.

name: Days Of Glory
desc: This film documents the heroism of those soldiers who fought shoulder to shoulder with the white men, but were denied equality.

name: Body of Lies
desc: Almost every film taking on the terrorist these days. But when you have Leornado DiCaprio on special operations to nab the Al Qaeda jihadis, terrorist hunting becomes special.

name: Star Wars: The Clone Wars
desc: Why would anyone want to replace the live action histrionics of the iconic Star Wars series with strangely animated creatures who can not create SFX magic of the Lucas pedigree.

name: Miss Pettigrew Lives For A Day
desc: Bharat Nalluri has created waves with his debut venture - a wacky comedy that re-creates the 1940s in London, even as it unfolds like a sweet, lyrical fairy tale about love and ever-after.

name: The Edge of Heaven
desc: Nejat, a Turkish professor who teaches German in a German university finds his life changing after his father brings in a Turkish hooker into the house.

name: Hellboy ll: The Golden Army
desc: That's the comic book hero Hellboy for you, who has his second outing under Guillermo Del Toro's creative expertise, and ends up better than his first avtar.

name: The Strangers
desc: Liv Tyler and Scott Speedman return from the woods to their home to resolve an unfinished quarrel but three strange, masked figures threaten to break into their house, for no reason at all.

name: Charlie Bartlett
desc: 17-year-old Charlie Bartlett is a worthy heir to Caulfield's rebellious teen angst in this smart teen comedy that brings back the dysfunctional 1970s-1980s, when teenagers hadn't yet transmuted into the well-adjusted I-pod generation.

name: The X-Files: I Want to Believe
desc: Scully and Mulder end up in hot pursuit of a maniac who is on the brink of conducting one of the most hair-raising experiments in medical surgery.

name: You Don't Mess With the Zohan
desc: It resolves the Israel-Palestinian conflict with it's schmaltzy love story between the Mossad counter-terrorist, Zohan (Adam Sandler) and the delightful Palestinian hair dresser, Dalia (Emmanuelle Chriqui).

name: Righteous Kill
desc: The magical chemistry is still there as the two veterans play NYPD cops who are trying to nab a psycopath; but age does seem to be catching up with two of Hollywood's greatest.

name: Mamma Mia
desc: The Devil gives up not only her Prada, but also her devilish ways and becomes a singing, dancing angelic muse in this breezy musical that lightens your heart and puts a song to your lips.

name: Padro Nuestro
desc: The film takes you on a journey through New York, like never before, where the glitter has been replaced by the grime; the hope by despair.

name: What Happens in Vegas
desc: This breezy comedy will leave you smiling and grinning with its rib-tickling battle of the sexes that rages on and on.

name: Wall-E
desc: An absolutely delightful futuristic parable, the film carries the Pixar legacy (remember Finding Nemo and Ratatouille?) forward.

name: Wanted
desc: Watch the film for its high-testosterone stunts and action sequences, although Jolie fans might end up somewhat disappointed by this outing.

name: Far North
desc: Two women and a man thrown together in the inhospitable Arctic Tundra can create some compelling drama. Specially since there's a shortage of both food and love.

name: Prom Night
desc: Speaking of prom nights and all the films that feature it Carrie remains the most memorable film, with the tele-kinetic teenager's nightmare still creating a chill amongst film buffs.

name: Sky Fighters
desc: The film keeps the adrenalin pumping with its tale of two fighter pilots, who end up saving Paris on Bastille Day from a bunch of terrorists who have stolen a Mirage and propose to create havoc with the flying machine.

name: Shortcut To Happiness
desc: The effect shows -- Baldwin sells his soul to devil, Jennifer Love Hewitt, lacks the sting of a delightfully devilish tale.

name: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor
desc: All you Mummy fans need not despair because there's a sequel in store, for the film ends with a teaser pointing to future action in Peru.

name: The Dark Knight
desc: Heath Ledger pitches in a breath-taking performance as Batman's arch rival in Christopher Nolan's breath-taking renditition of the comic book hero's second caper after Batman Begins.

name: Goodbye Bafana
desc: Based on the controversial book by prison guard James Gregory, Goodbye Bafana traces his relationship with Nelson Mandela that covers a span of almost two decades.

name: The Other Boleyn Girl
desc: It's a drama of love, passion and desertion set against the backdrop of the Tudor period, where a brooding King Henry V111 (Eric Bana) is desperate to have a male heir for the throne of England.

name: The Lives of Others
desc: This German film which won the Oscar for Best Foreign film last year and several other international awards is truly a sonata to human goodness.

name: Kung Fu Panda
desc: He's THE Big Fat Panda! True. Salutations to one of the sweetest, funniest animation hero to be seen on the screen, of late.

name: Hancock
desc: It's the season of super heroes in Hollywood. Close on the heels of Iron Man, Indiana Jones and The Incredible Hulk comes Hancock.

name: Caramel
desc: Here's a Lebanese take on Sex and the City which captures the lives of a bunch of women in Beirut, as they struggle to find love and happiness.

name: Made of Honor
desc: The chemistry may be a bit tepid and the plot somewhat tardy and foregone, but there's enough for Dempsey fans to get dreamy about.

name: Charlie Bartlett
desc: Compelling performances by Robert Downey Jr and Anton Yelchin coupled with an undercurrent of comedy make this an interesting film that mirrors high school life with all its highs and lows.

name: Get Smart
desc: Now this one's quite a funny spoof on the James Bond series, in league with Austin Powers' ass-brained mission to save the world.

name: Sex and the City
desc: No, this one's not merely a chick flick. Not with its sassy look at urban relationships and its sane advice: let's not brand relationships and box them into conventions.

name: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull
desc: It's a great comeback for the quintessential adventurer, Henry Jones Junior (Harrison Ford) who may be 65 years old, but he is still not willing to relinquish his characteristic hat to Henry Jones Junior 11.

name: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian
desc: Loads of computer-generated wizardry, an edge of teen romance and the usual ode to valour and justice: this second part in C.S. Lewis' seven part fantasy has the requisite thrills.

name: Speed Racer
desc: Speed Racer is a film that breaks all the stereotypes, even though it dabbles with nothing but stereotypes. Don't miss this post-modern pulp fiction.

name: Iron Man
desc: Iron Man may not have been the Big Hero of Marvel Comics, but here, in his first film avtar, he stands as tall as the rest of masked crusaders. Behold! a hero is born.

name: Dr Seuss Horton hears a Who
desc: This one's a sweet little parable on politics with its cutesy diatribe against big worlds swallowing small worlds. Go for it.

name: Juno
desc: Here's a film that tackles a tangled topic -- teen pregnancy -- without getting into knots and tangles. It's such a fresh, uncomplicated look at one of the most compelling problems today.

name: Meet the Spartans
desc: The film chooses to spoof any and everything that has been entertainment news including a bald Britney, Brangelina's adoption bid, Paris Hilton and her pet dog. Too crowded, clumsy and kitchy.

name: D-War
desc: The film blends the occidental and the oriental as it moves between America, here and now, and Korea's Chosun dynasty, 500 years ago.

name: The Bucket List
desc: A sweet, feel good film about death and friendship, The Bucket List is more about kalakars (actors) than kahani (story).

name: The Ex
desc: There's nothing smart about this two-boys-one-girl romance which sorely lacks a comedy track, despite being mounted as a comedy.

name: August Rush
desc: Truly dreamy, with loads of great music and stunning visuals, this is predictable, yet watchable fare. More importantly, it's Charles Dickens, revisited, albeit as a musical.

name: We Own The Night
desc: The predictable script and the formulaic twists and turns reduce the film to a run-of-the-mill, albeit watchable film.

name: 10,000 BC
desc: The story is more exciting to read than to see, for although the canvas is large, the thrills are not larger-than-life.

name: Letters From Iwo Jima
desc: In the end, Letters... is a moving -- and artistic -- indictment of war and violence which should actually have no place in global politics.

name: Vantage Point
desc: The interesting part is the eight versions of the assassination attempt, as the event is told -- and re-told -- through the eyes of the different people who were present there.

name: There Will Be Blood
desc: Watch it for Anderson's eye for detail and for Daniel Day-Lewis who lends grandeur a period charm to Plainview despite his questionable motives.

name: Michael Clayton
desc: The narrative gets somewhat dense, here and there, but leave it to Clooney to carry you through this legal maze that takes a detour into the character's personal hell.

name: The Nanny Diaries
desc: If you loved The Devil Wears Prada, rest assured, you will like this one. Because both the films follow the same storyline.

name: Enchanted
desc: This is crazy, zany and absolutely delightful Disney fare that is determined to light up your evening with its brilliant re-writing of the quintessential fairy tale.

name: August Rush
desc: Truly dreamy, with loads of great music and stunning visuals, this is predictable, yet watchable fare. More importantly, it's Charles Dickens, revisited, albeit as a musical.

name: Turistas
desc: This blood and gore fest, which unfolds either in an underlit house or the dark underwaters of the Brazilian sea shore, is simply barbaric.

name: Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem
desc: It seems like the directors have smartly served up a sci-fi film so that blood could flow, and it does. Unfortunately, it doesn't flow with much imagination.

name: Rambo 4
desc: For all those who got hooked on to Rambo's exploits in First Blood, his Fourth Blood heroics may bring back nostalgic memories of a cold and clinical killing machine.

name: Alvin and the Chipmunks
desc: Like all sweet films, this one too serenades family values as invaluable, transcending money, glamour and the glitzy glutton's life.

name: National Treasure: Book of Secrets
desc: Loads of insipid rummaging through history's memorabilia followed by some uneventful trips to discover a forgotten city of gold don't actually make for a thrilling adventure.

name: Fur
desc: The film has a slow, languorous pace which might put off many, but for those who like a different cinematic experience, Fur could end up as engaging cinema.

name: The Jane Austen Book Club
desc: Go find an Emma, a Darcy in this contemporary homage to Austen's sense and sensibility. A must for all Austen-philes.

name: Nancy Drew Get a Clue
desc: If you've grown up on Nancy Drew stories, the staple fare for post-Enid Blyton, pre-Harold Robbins bookworms, you sure are gonna be disappointed by this one.
The film focuses on the nightmarish experience of a writer who checks into the haunted room to get inspiration for his next bestseller.

name: Bee Movie
desc: Enough to make you sit back and laugh as you watch a stingy little fella called Barry Bee make a beeline for humankind and teach them how to bee-have.

name: Hitman
desc: Hitman is one more game from Playstation to find its way on to the big screen. And like the rest of the kick butt series, this too ends up minus all thrills in its bigger avatar.

name: Beowulf
desc: The ancient English epic poem about a hero comes to life in a state-of-the-art film which is absolutely new, novel and different in terms of technique.

name: Elizabeth, The Golden Age
desc: This one is laboured and has nothing new to offer, other than a power-packed performance by Cate Blanchett who plays the eponymous role with gusto and verve.

name: A Mighty Heart
desc: Winterbottom's take on the Daniel Pearl murder is an edge of the seat thriller that hits hard, and touches your heart.

name: The Contract
desc: The film should have actually been quite average, if it wasn't for Morgan Freeman who adds gravitas to whatever he does.

name: The Bourne Ultimatum
desc: This third film in the Bourne trilogy is a relentless action stunner which doesn't let you sit back for a moment. Go, get your thrills.

name: Blind Dating
desc: There's one big reason why you should watch this film; only one. And that's the fact that we have an Indian playing the heroine to an all-American hero.

name: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix
Stardust
desc: Here’s a quixotic pariyon ki kahani for adults, laced with delicious fantasy, dreamy landscapes and an allegorical tenor that makes Stardust a watchable parable on love and life.

name: Marigold
desc: A bit more energy and the film could have been a sweet crossover romance. But then, haven’t we seen enough of the half-baked versions of desi-pardesi couplings.

name: The Kingdom
desc: There's nothing new to keep you glued, despite the fact that Jamie Foxx and Chris Cooper are amongst the diehard dependables of Hollywood. Blame it on the unimaginative script.

name: The Simpsons Movie
desc: The film is meant to make you sit back and have fun while America's No.l dysfunctional family sets the world in disorder.

name: The Host
desc: The film is a country cousin of the hi-tech dinos of Spielberg's super thriller. We need to have imports that are quintessentially Korean rather than pale copies of Hollywood.

name: 30 Days of Night
desc: Now if Hollywood wants to make another vampire film, it needs to add something new. No more of those bloody fangs on those ashen faces, please.

name: Resident Evil: Extinction
desc: It’s the third in the Resident Evil franchise which is based on the popular Capcom video game series. And it is the best when compared to the earlier two, Resident Evil and Resident Evil Apocalypse.

name: Rush Hour 3
desc: Prolonged paisa vasool action sequences on the multi-storeyed metal marvel coupled with quirky Tucker humour and cheesy Chan chopsucky could make for mirthful timepass.

name: Premonition
desc: A super-natural thriller, the film could have been a Sixth Sense or a Memento. It isn’t. Instead, it ends up as rather drab.

name: Lions for Lambs
desc: The film is essentially one long conversation, divided into three sequences. Nevertheless, you listen because it is a topical and sensible diatribe against post 9/11 America.

name: Next
desc: It's time to duck bullets and dodge canons, as clairvoyant Cage tries to save the nation and his nymph. Interesting.

name: No Reservations
desc: Watch out for the heart tugging sequences between the little miss Abigail and Zeta-Jones who graduates from imperfect mother to perfect guardian.

name: Because I Said So
desc: The funny parts are laidback, the romantic bits hardly sizzle and the acting isn't much to write about, yet the film strikes a chord.

name: Hannibal Rising
desc: It may not be as rivetting as The Silence of the Lambs, but Hannibal Rising is a gritty fare. Indeed, a strange new world in cinema!

name: Fantastic Four 2: Rise of the Silver Surfer
